headline: To Catch a Hacker
abstract: President Obama has given the Treasury Department power to issue financial sanctions against hackers. Will it help?
snippet: President Obama has given the Treasury Department power to issue financial sanctions against hackers. Will it help?
lead_paragraph: One reason American businesses and the government remain vulnerable to foreign hackers is that it is incredibly hard to arrest and prosecute those criminals. Responding to that difficulty, President Obama is giving the Treasury Department the power to issue financial sanctions against hackers and the people and businesses that hire them to conduct cyber attacks.

headline: Attack on GitHub Appears to Have Ended
abstract: The site that hosts code for programmers had been overwhelmed by traffic that security experts believed came from China’s Great Firewall.
snippet: The site that hosts code for programmers had been overwhelmed by traffic that security experts believed came from China’s Great Firewall.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s great coding libraries is safe, for now.

headline: Report Credits F.B.I. With Progress Since 9/11, but Says More Is Needed
abstract: The bureau needs to improve intelligence capabilities and hire more linguists, said the report, which looked at progress since the Sept. 11 attacks.
snippet: The bureau needs to improve intelligence capabilities and hire more linguists, said the report, which looked at progress since the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has made great strides since the Sept. 11 attacks but urgently needs to improve its intelligence capabilities, hire more linguists and elevate the stature of its analysts to counter the rapidly evolving threats to the United States, according to a report released on Wednesday.

headline: Behind a Veil of Anonymity, Online Vigilantes Battle the Islamic State
abstract: A loosely organized effort by computer hacking collectives aimed at disrupting ISIS and other violent jihadist causes began last year after the group posted images of beheaded captives.
snippet: A loosely organized effort by computer hacking collectives aimed at disrupting ISIS and other violent jihadist causes began last year after the group posted images of beheaded captives.
lead_paragraph: They use screen aliases like IS Hunting Club, TouchMyTweets and The Doctor. They troll Twitter for suspected accounts of Islamic State fighters, recruiters and fund-raisers. Then they pounce.

headline: U.S. Must Step Up Capacity for Cyberattacks, Chief Argues
abstract: Adm. Michael S. Rogers, the head of United States Cyber Command, said in Senate testimony that the country needed to increase its capacity for cyberattacks as a deterrent against hostile nations.
snippet: Adm. Michael S. Rogers, the head of United States Cyber Command, said in Senate testimony that the country needed to increase its capacity for cyberattacks as a deterrent against hostile nations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The admiral who directs American cyberforces told a Senate committee on Thursday that the United States was “at a tipping point” where it needed to increase its ability to conduct cyberattacks, to create a deterrent against other countries that are attacking it.

headline: Authorities Closing In on Hackers Who Stole Data From JPMorgan Chase
abstract: Authorities anticipate capturing the architects of the JPMorgan Chase data breach, which they hope may turn the tide on such investigations, which often go unresolved.
snippet: Authorities anticipate capturing the architects of the JPMorgan Chase data breach, which they hope may turn the tide on such investigations, which often go unresolved.
lead_paragraph: It has become a familiar pattern: The computer system of a big American company is breached, the personal information of tens of millions of customers is stolen and a public outcry ensues. Rarely are the thieves caught.

headline: Briton Arrested Over Cyberattack on U.S. Defense Department
abstract: Data were stolen in June from a messaging service used by the department’s employees, including email addresses and phone numbers for about 800 contacts.
snippet: Data were stolen in June from a messaging service used by the department’s employees, including email addresses and phone numbers for about 800 contacts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 23-year-old British man has been arrested over a cyberattack in which data was stolen from the United States Department of Defense, the police said on Friday.

headline: Review: In ‘CSI: Cyber,’ CBS Digitizes the Forensics Formula
abstract: The latest “CSI” spinoff stars Patricia Arquette as a cybercrime investigator.
snippet: The latest “CSI” spinoff stars Patricia Arquette as a cybercrime investigator.
lead_paragraph: “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,” now chugging along in its 15th season, keeps leaving its spinoffs in the dust. “CSI: Miami” gave up after 10 seasons, “CSI: NY” fell away after nine. But the hope for advertising dollars springs eternal, so here we have “CSI: Cyber,” making its debut on CBS on Wednesday night.

headline: Document Reveals Growth of Cyberwarfare Between the U.S. and Iran
abstract: A newly disclosed National Security Agency document shows the drastic acceleration of the use of cyberweapons by the United States and Iran against each other.
snippet: A newly disclosed National Security Agency document shows the drastic acceleration of the use of cyberweapons by the United States and Iran against each other.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A newly disclosed National Security Agency document illustrates the striking acceleration of the use of cyberweapons by the United States and Iran against each other, both for spying and sabotage, even as Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart met in Geneva to try to break a stalemate in the talks over Iran’s disputed nuclear program.

headline: U.S. Embedded Spyware Overseas, Report Claims
abstract: A Russian firm said that the United States had found a way to permanently embed surveillance and sabotage tools in computers in nations like Iran, Russia, Pakistan and China.
snippet: A Russian firm said that the United States had found a way to permanently embed surveillance and sabotage tools in computers in nations like Iran, Russia, Pakistan and China.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The United States has found a way to permanently embed surveillance and sabotage tools in computers and networks it has targeted in Iran, Russia, Pakistan, China, Afghanistan and other countries closely watched by American intelligence agencies, according to a Russian cybersecurity firm.

As Joel Flynn reports, it's the latest in the online battle between criminals and law enforcement.

headline: Millions of Anthem Customers Targeted in Cyberattack
abstract: The insurer said hackers were able to breach a database that contained as many as 80 million records of current and former customers, including names, Social Security numbers and income data.
snippet: The insurer said hackers were able to breach a database that contained as many as 80 million records of current and former customers, including names, Social Security numbers and income data.
lead_paragraph: Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, said late Wednesday that the personal information of tens of millions of its customers and employees, including its chief executive, was the subject of a “very sophisticated external cyberattack.”

headline: Brokerage Firms Worry About Breaches by Hackers, Not Terrorists
abstract: The report recommended that all brokerage firms assess their security and review the safeguards put in place by their vendors, after finding that a small minority of firms are not yet doing so.
snippet: The report recommended that all brokerage firms assess their security and review the safeguards put in place by their vendors, after finding that a small minority of firms are not yet doing so.
lead_paragraph: The online attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment in the fall that federal authorities linked to the North Korean government raised alarm bells about the hacking threat posed by foreign governments. But brokerage firms based in the United States remain most concerned about an attack carried out by a loose band of hackers or employees with a grudge.

headline: Sundance 2015: Documentaries Suddenly Made Timely
abstract: News events have made four nonfiction entries in the festival very relevant.
snippet: News events have made four nonfiction entries in the festival very relevant.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – If timing is everything, then four documentary filmmakers are about to have a very good run in this resort town.

headline: Analysis of Obama’s State of the Union Address
abstract: President Obama will deliver his State of the Union address Tuesday night, outlining his agenda in front of a joint session of Congress fully controlled by Republicans for the first time in his presidency.
snippet: President Obama will deliver his State of the Union address Tuesday night, outlining his agenda in front of a joint session of Congress fully controlled by Republicans for the first time in his presidency.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, outlining his agenda in front of a joint session of Congress, which is fully controlled by Republicans for the first time in his presidency.

headline: Need Some Espionage Done? Hackers Are for Hire Online
abstract: No longer just the domain of intelligence agencies, “hacktivists” or criminal gangs, there is a growing cottage industry of ordinary people hiring hackers for much smaller acts of espionage.
snippet: No longer just the domain of intelligence agencies, “hacktivists” or criminal gangs, there is a growing cottage industry of ordinary people hiring hackers for much smaller acts of espionage.
lead_paragraph: A man in Sweden says he will pay up to $2,000 to anyone who can break into his landlord’s website. A woman in California says she will pay $500 for someone to hack into her boyfriend’s Facebook and Gmail accounts to see if he is cheating on her.

headline: Unshackled Hacker Dons a White Hat
abstract: In Michael Mann’s “Blackhat,” a hacker is provisionally released from prison to combat a cybercriminal who has sabotaged a nuclear plant and manipulated a financial market.
snippet: In Michael Mann’s “Blackhat,” a hacker is provisionally released from prison to combat a cybercriminal who has sabotaged a nuclear plant and manipulated a financial market.
lead_paragraph: Michael Mann’s thriller “Blackhat,” a story about the intersection of bodies and machines, is a spectacular work of unhinged moviemaking. By turns brutal and sentimental, lovely and lurid, as serious as the grave and blissfully preposterous, it combines a truckload of plot with many of the obsessions, tropes, sights and sounds that distinguish his other movies, from kinetic gun battles to cool beauties gazing into the distance in sunglasses. Here those beauties are a pair of improbable computer savants, played by Chris Hemsworth and Tang Wei, who race, jet and furiously bang on keyboards across the globe while chasing villainy, lines of code and millions in loot.

headline: No Safety for Christians in the Mideast
abstract: For decades, Christian communities in the Middle East have dwindled, and an acceleration of this trend is fundamentally rewriting the region's demography.
snippet: For decades, Christian communities in the Middle East have dwindled, and an acceleration of this trend is fundamentally rewriting the region's demography.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It has been that time of year when Christians, in the West at least, gather to count their blessings. Churches more used to the murmured orisons of shrinking congregations suddenly fill with worshipers singing carols, punctuating less-spiritual rites of frenetic spending that mimic the feast days of the faithful — Black Friday, Cyber Monday.

headline: F.B.I. Says Little Doubt North Korea Hit Sony
abstract: Instead of routing their attacks through decoy servers, the hackers sent them directly from web addresses in North Korea, the F.B.I. said. But some skeptics still wanted to see the agency’s evidence.
snippet: Instead of routing their attacks through decoy servers, the hackers sent them directly from web addresses in North Korea, the F.B.I. said. But some skeptics still wanted to see the agency’s evidence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I.’s director, James B. Comey, said on Wednesday that the United States had concluded that North Korea was behind the destructive attacks on Sony Pictures partly because the hackers failed to mask their location when they broke into the company’s servers.

headline: University in Xi’an Opens School of Cyberengineering
abstract: The move by Xidian University, with more than 30,000 students on two campuses, was a sign that cybersecurity had become an increasingly important academic discipline for the Chinese government and military.
snippet: The move by Xidian University, with more than 30,000 students on two campuses, was a sign that cybersecurity had become an increasingly important academic discipline for the Chinese government and military.
lead_paragraph: Xidian University, with more than 30,000 students on two campuses in the ancient city of Xi’an, has a storied history. The original academy was personally established by Mao Zedong in 1931, when the Communist Party and Red Army were leading an insurgent movement to overthrow the Kuomintang government. Based in Jiangxi Province, where the Communists had their headquarters for a period, the school’s mission was to train radio operators for the military. Mao had set it up in his role as head of the party’s Central Military Commission.

headline: Countering Cyberattacks Without a Playbook
abstract: Because there are no international treaties or norms about how to use digital weapons, there are no rules about how to fight conflicts like the one spawned by the digital attack on Sony Pictures.
snippet: Because there are no international treaties or norms about how to use digital weapons, there are no rules about how to fight conflicts like the one spawned by the digital attack on Sony Pictures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years now, the Obama administration has warned of the risks of a “cyber-Pearl Harbor,” a nightmare attack that takes out America’s power grids and cellphone networks and looks like the opening battle in a full-scale digital war.

headline: U.S. Asks China to Help Rein In Korean Hackers
abstract: As part of its response to the cyberattack on Sony Pictures, the Obama administration has asked China to assist in blocking North Korea’s ability to launch such attacks.
snippet: As part of its response to the cyberattack on Sony Pictures, the Obama administration has asked China to assist in blocking North Korea’s ability to launch such attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has sought China’s help in recent days in blocking North Korea’s ability to launch cyberattacks, the first steps toward the “proportional response” President Obama vowed to make the North pay for the assault on Sony Pictures — and as part of a campaign to issue a broader warning against future hacking, according to senior administration officials.

headline: Millennials and the Age of Tumblr Activism
abstract: A generation called apathetic is speaking out on Tumblr.
snippet: A generation called apathetic is speaking out on Tumblr.
lead_paragraph: On a recent day, the feed of a Tumblr blog called Black Culture featured a drawing of Lupita Nyong’o, a video of a protest at William Paterson University and a text that read, “black lives > white feelings.” The blog FreeQuency Frequently Writes posted a Tweet from Solange Knowles decrying depictions of outspoken women, while another called Soul Revision turned up a post with the hashtags #SeasonOfInconvenience and #BlackLivesMatter.

headline: Obama vows response to North Korea over attack

headline: Why We Don’t Offer Black Friday Discounts
abstract: Instead of putting stuff on sale, we came up with an exclusive, limited-edition collection of products — at their regular prices.
snippet: Instead of putting stuff on sale, we came up with an exclusive, limited-edition collection of products — at their regular prices.
lead_paragraph: On the Monday before Black Friday, one of our longtime retail employees came into my office seeking advice. She was thinking about creating a Facebook post aimed at our local customers and offering some secret in-store-only specials on Black Friday. She knew we shied away from discounts at Jimmy Beans Wool, but she wanted to double-check.

headline: Teaching About Cybersecurity: Taking Steps to Improve Online Safety and Prevent Data Breaches
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the extent of cyberattacks just in the past year and the risks they pose for companies, governments and individuals.
snippet: In this lesson, students will learn about the extent of cyberattacks just in the past year and the risks they pose for companies, governments and individuals.
lead_paragraph: Overview | From data breaches at Target, Home Depot, JPMorgan and even the White House to celebrities’ stolen photos, cybersecurity and online privacy have been making the headlines every week. But how do data breaches at companies and government institutions affect individuals? What can individuals do to enhance their digital security?

snippet: Ian Urbina describes how he reported his Times Magazine story “The Secret Life of Passwords.”

headline: Luck Played Role in Discovery of Data Breach at JPMorgan Affecting Millions

snippet: The bank was able to identify intruders on its network by looking for digital fingerprints seen on a trove of stolen data uncovered elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to defending a large company against an online attack, sometimes luck and timing can mean as much as spending hundreds of millions of dollars a year on computer security.

headline: New Russian Boldness Revives a Cold War Tradition: Testing the Other Side
abstract: A breach of a White House computer system and military flights skirting NATO territory could be “message-sending by Putin, and it’s dangerous,” a defense official said.
snippet: A breach of a White House computer system and military flights skirting NATO territory could be “message-sending by Putin, and it’s dangerous,” a defense official said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the White House discovered in recent weeks that its unclassified computer systems had been breached, intelligence officials examined the digital evidence and focused on a prime suspect: Russia, which they believe is using its highly sophisticated cyber capabilities to test American defenses. But its tracks were well covered, and officials say they may never know for sure.
