headline: JPMorgan Chase Hacking Affects 76 Million Households
abstract: The disclosure by the bank dwarfs earlier estimates that attackers had gained access to roughly one million customer accounts.
snippet: The disclosure by the bank dwarfs earlier estimates that attackers had gained access to roughly one million customer accounts.
lead_paragraph: A cyberattack this summer on JPMorgan Chase compromised the accounts of 76 million households and seven million small businesses, a tally that dwarfs previous estimates by the bank and puts the intrusion among the largest ever.

headline: Protecting Your Business From a Data Breach
abstract: Small businesses generally are even more vulnerable than large companies.
snippet: Small businesses generally are even more vulnerable than large companies.
lead_paragraph: This year, Home Depot’s in-store payment system was hacked in what may have been the largest data breach of a retail company’s computer network. It is unlikely to be the last.

headline: China's Fruitless Repression of the Uighurs
abstract: Ilham Tohti's only "crime" was to advocate for China's own policies for autonomy for ethnic minorities.
snippet: Ilham Tohti's only "crime" was to advocate for China's own policies for autonomy for ethnic minorities.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a court in China’s far western Xinjiang region sentenced Ilham Tohti, a member of the Uighur minority, to life in prison for the crime of “inciting separatism.” The conviction of this moderate scholar elicited international condemnation; the sentence was an order of magnitude longer than those given to other Chinese dissidents. But, far from being a show of strength, the sentence is a sign of the confusion and desperation behind the government’s policies toward Uighurs.

headline: Narendra Modi, in U.N. Speech, Inserts India Into Terrorism Fight
abstract: Indian’s prime minister made his first speech at the United Nations General Assembly.
snippet: Indian’s prime minister made his first speech at the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India reminded the world on Saturday of his country’s abiding battle against extremist groups, and took a swipe at countries that give them shelter before capping his speech with a call for an International Yoga Day.

headline: How a Times Cybersecurity Reporter Protects Her Data. And What You Can Do to Protect Yours.
abstract: Times technology reporter Nicole Perlroth shares her thoughts on cybersecurity, on how she protects her online identity, and how you should protect yours.
snippet: Times technology reporter Nicole Perlroth shares her thoughts on cybersecurity, on how she protects her online identity, and how you should protect yours.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Perlroth covers cybersecurity and privacy. Last week she wrote on Home Depot’s confirmation that hackers had broken into its in-store payments systems in what could be the largest-known breach of a retail company’s computer network. She shares her thoughts on security and personal data with Times Insiders.

headline: Apple’s Live-Streaming Is Terrible
abstract: While the company makes its much-anticipated announcements about its new products, it seems to be having a lot of trouble with the live-streaming of the event.
snippet: While the company makes its much-anticipated announcements about its new products, it seems to be having a lot of trouble with the live-streaming of the event.
lead_paragraph: Finally, Apple’s product announcements have arrived. But for anyone wanting to watch the live-streaming, well, it’s extremely awkward.

headline: Weighing In on Paid Interethnic Marriages in Xinjiang
abstract: In an effort to defuse ethnic tensions, a county in a Western region of China is trying to encourage marriage between Uighurs and Han by offering cash and other incentives. Two experts put the efforts into context.
snippet: In an effort to defuse ethnic tensions, a county in a Western region of China is trying to encourage marriage between Uighurs and Han by offering cash and other incentives. Two experts put the efforts into context.
lead_paragraph: This week, The New York Times reported on officials in a county in the western region of Xinjiang offering cash and other incentives to encourage more interethnic marriages, with the goal of defusing ethnic tensions. Many Chinese officials are concerned about increasingly violent conflicts between Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking, mostly Muslim people who populate large parts of Xinjiang, and the Han, the dominant ethnicity in China. At a two-day work forum on Xinjiang in May, President Xi Jinping called for new policies to better assimilate Uighurs into mainstream Chinese society.

headline: NATO Set to Ratify Pledge on Joint Defense in Case of Major Cyberattack
abstract: For the first time, a cyberattack on any of the 28 NATO nations could be declared an attack on all of them, much like a ground invasion or an airborne bombing.
snippet: For the first time, a cyberattack on any of the 28 NATO nations could be declared an attack on all of them, much like a ground invasion or an airborne bombing.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When President Obama meets with other NATO leaders later this week, they are expected to ratify what seems, at first glance, a far-reaching change in the organization’s mission of collective defense: For the first time, a cyberattack on any of the 28 NATO nations could be declared an attack on all of them, much like a ground invasion or an airborne bombing.

headline: Fighting Credit Card Fraud
abstract: The chief executive of the Electronic Transactions Association discusses efforts to thwart cyber thieves.
snippet: The chief executive of the Electronic Transactions Association discusses efforts to thwart cyber thieves.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: JPMorgan Chase confirms possible cyber attack
abstract: Attackers stole checking and savings account information and lots of other data from JPMorgan Chase, according to the New York Times. Other banks are believed to be victims as well. Fred Katayama reports.
snippet: Attackers stole checking and savings account information and lots of other data from JPMorgan Chase, according to the New York Times. Other banks are believed to be victims as well. Fred Katayama reports.
lead_paragraph: Attackers stole checking and savings account information and lots of other data from JPMorgan Chase, according to the New York Times. Other banks are believed to be victims as well. Fred Katayama reports.

headline: JPMorgan Chase confirms possible cyber attack
abstract: Attackers stole checking and savings account information and lots of other data from JPMorgan Chase, according to the New York Times. Other banks are believed to be victims as well. Fred Katayama reports.
snippet: Attackers stole checking and savings account information and lots of other data from JPMorgan Chase, according to the New York Times. Other banks are believed to be victims as well. Fred Katayama reports.
lead_paragraph: Attackers stole checking and savings account information and lots of other data from JPMorgan Chase, according to the New York Times. Other banks are believed to be victims as well. Fred Katayama reports.

headline: Does Where You Live Make a Difference in How and What You Write?
abstract: Mohsin Hamid and Thomas Mallon discuss how where they’ve lived has affected their work.
snippet: Mohsin Hamid and Thomas Mallon discuss how where they’ve lived has affected their work.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Mohsin Hamid and Thomas Mallon discuss how where they’ve lived has affected their work.

headline: Hackers Target Video Games for Fun, Profit and Better Scores
abstract: Sophisticated hackers are infiltrating video game makers not only to steal credit card numbers, passwords and trade secrets, but also, it turns out, simply for the virtual street cred.
snippet: Sophisticated hackers are infiltrating video game makers not only to steal credit card numbers, passwords and trade secrets, but also, it turns out, simply for the virtual street cred.
lead_paragraph: Hackers are breaking into American companies for credit card numbers, passwords, trade secrets and — it turns out — for phony video game scores.

headline: Hack of Community Health Systems Affects 4.5 Million Patients
abstract: On Monday, a hospital network said personal data for 4.5 million patients had been stolen in a cyberattack by a group based in China.
snippet: On Monday, a hospital network said personal data for 4.5 million patients had been stolen in a cyberattack by a group based in China.
lead_paragraph: Community Health Systems, a publicly traded hospital operator based in Franklin, Tenn., said that personal data, including names, Social Security numbers and addresses, for 4.5 million patients had been compromised in a Chinese cyberattack on its systems from April to June.

headline: Chinese Businessman Is Charged in Plot to Steal U.S. Military Data
abstract: The owner of a Chinese aviation company spent years taking data from Boeing on military aircraft and weapons, the Justice Department said.
snippet: The owner of a Chinese aviation company spent years taking data from Boeing on military aircraft and weapons, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Chinese businessman in Canada hacked into Boeing’s computers and stole information about United States military aircraft and weapons, the Justice Department said on Friday, describing a corporate espionage case that is unusual for the huge amount of data involved.

headline: Kerry Assures China That the U.S. Can Have Many Allies in Asia
abstract: The secretary of state sought to highlight commonalities between China and the United States after the Chinese dismissed assertions that hackers had infiltrated federal computer systems.
snippet: The secretary of state sought to highlight commonalities between China and the United States after the Chinese dismissed assertions that hackers had infiltrated federal computer systems.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Seeking to put the best face on a difficult relationship with Beijing, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that the United States and China could find ways to manage their differences and had more in common than not.

headline: Security Firm Described Simulation as Real Hack
abstract: BAE Systems Applied Intelligence retracts claims it helped thwart a sophisticated cyberattack at a hedge fund. The attack was not an attack at all. It was a simulation.
snippet: BAE Systems Applied Intelligence retracts claims it helped thwart a sophisticated cyberattack at a hedge fund. The attack was not an attack at all. It was a simulation.
lead_paragraph: BAE Systems Applied Intelligence, a defense, aerospace and security company, recently noted in a report that one of its clients at an unnamed hedge fund lost millions of dollars because of a cyberattack. But the incident was, in fact, a simulation run by the security firm itself.

headline: New N.S.A. Chief Calls Damage From Snowden Leaks Manageable
abstract: The director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Michael S. Rogers, described the steps the agency is taking to ensure that no one else can download the information taken by Edward J. Snowden, a former defense contractor.
snippet: The director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Michael S. Rogers, described the steps the agency is taking to ensure that no one else can download the information taken by Edward J. Snowden, a former defense contractor.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The newly installed director of the National Security Agency says that while he has seen some terrorist groups alter their communications to avoid surveillance techniques revealed by Edward J. Snowden, the damage done over all by a year of revelations does not lead him to the conclusion that “the sky is falling.”

headline: Hacker Tactic: Holding Data Hostage
abstract: Cybercriminals are finding new ways to breach firewalls and hold data hostage.
snippet: Cybercriminals are finding new ways to breach firewalls and hold data hostage.
lead_paragraph: THE perpetual cat-and-mouse game between computer hackers and their targets is getting nastier. Cybercriminals are getting better at circumventing firewalls and antivirus programs. More of them are resorting to ransomware, which encrypts computer data and holds it hostage until a fee is paid. Some hackers plant virus-loaded ads on legitimate websites, enabling them to remotely wipe a hard drive clean or cause it to overheat. Meanwhile, companies are being routinely targeted by attacks sponsored by the governments of Iran and China. Even small start-ups are suffering from denial-of-service extortion attacks, in which hackers threaten to disable their websites unless money is paid.

headline: Reinventing Emily Gould
abstract: A former serpent-tongued devil behind Gawker and a proponent of oversharing now disdains the kind of attention that once defined her.
snippet: A former serpent-tongued devil behind Gawker and a proponent of oversharing now disdains the kind of attention that once defined her.
lead_paragraph: Emily Gould stood posing for a photograph on West 29th Street in front of the building where she works, wearing a stone-colored cardigan, her hair scraped back into a messy ponytail, her only concession to vanity a slash of red lipstick applied with apparent indifference.

headline: Tally of Cyber Extortion Attacks on Tech Companies Grows
abstract: A flood of extortion attempts against web start-ups that began earlier this year appears to be getting worse. Evernote, Feedly, Moz and, this week, Move, an online real estate service, have been targeted in the last month.
snippet: A flood of extortion attempts against web start-ups that began earlier this year appears to be getting worse. Evernote, Feedly, Moz and, this week, Move, an online real estate service, have been targeted in the last month.
lead_paragraph: Tech start-ups continue to get hit by extortion attempts from cybercriminals who aim to shut down their systems until companies pay their ransom.

headline: Rise of the Internet Hate Machine
abstract: The Internet has made it easier than ever before for foul-mouthed, often sexist haters to air their grievances without consequence, writes JAKE FLANAGIN.
snippet: The Internet has made it easier than ever before for foul-mouthed, often sexist haters to air their grievances without consequence, writes JAKE FLANAGIN.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the age of Internet hate, when “it’s never been easier to send an anonymous death threat,” writes Jack Shafer for Reuters. “As with so many of life’s labors, advanced technology has removed most of the work and hazard from sending cowardly messages to people to frighten them.”

headline: Automating Cybersecurity
abstract: A Defense Department agency is holding a contest to encourage programmers to create automation tools to find flaws in computer systems, like ones that make data vulnerable to theft.
snippet: A Defense Department agency is holding a contest to encourage programmers to create automation tools to find flaws in computer systems, like ones that make data vulnerable to theft.
lead_paragraph: If only computers themselves were smart enough to fight off malevolent hackers.

headline: American Businesses in China Feel Heat of a Cyberdispute
abstract: Following the Justice Department’s indictment of five members of the Chinese Army on economic cyberespionage charges, Chinese government agencies are reviewing their use of IBM servers — an example of the growing tensions.
snippet: Following the Justice Department’s indictment of five members of the Chinese Army on economic cyberespionage charges, Chinese government agencies are reviewing their use of IBM servers — an example of the growing tensions.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A top Chinese general was in a combative mood as he presided recently over an international security forum at a historic hotel near the Forbidden City. Among the attendees were a retired American admiral and a former American diplomat.

headline: Beijing Levels New Attack at U.S. Cyber-Spying
abstract: In a lengthy, political indictment of American cyber-espionage, a Chinese government agency has accused the Obama administration of spying on the Internet on a scale far greater than that of other countries.
snippet: In a lengthy, political indictment of American cyber-espionage, a Chinese government agency has accused the Obama administration of spying on the Internet on a scale far greater than that of other countries.
lead_paragraph: A week after United States prosecutors  indicted  five People’s Liberation Army officers on charges of cyber-theft, a Chinese government agency has issued its own lengthy, political indictment of American cyber-espionage, accusing the Obama administration of spying on the Internet on a scale far greater than that of other countries.

headline: Q & A: Adam Segal on China, Cyberspies and the Moral High Ground
abstract: Adam M. Segal, an expert on China and cybersecurity at the Council on Foreign Relations, discussed the clash between the United States and China over cyberspying.
snippet: Adam M. Segal, an expert on China and cybersecurity at the Council on Foreign Relations, discussed the clash between the United States and China over cyberspying.
lead_paragraph: This week, the United States took its most aggressive step yet in trying to curb what it calls Chinese state-sponsored hacking attacks aimed at stealing trade secrets from American corporations. The Justice Department on Monday announced an indictment against five members of the People’s Liberation Army accused of corporate cyberespionage. United States officials say the five men belong to Unit 61398, which operates out of an office tower on the outskirts of Shanghai.

headline: Hacking Charges Threaten Further Damage to Chinese-American Relations
abstract: Administration officials said the tough measure was adopted after President Xi Jinping brushed off President Obama’s demands that the Chinese government curb the hacking of American companies.
snippet: Administration officials said the tough measure was adopted after President Xi Jinping brushed off President Obama’s demands that the Chinese government curb the hacking of American companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama was not involved in the decision to indict five members of the People’s Liberation Army, an administration official said on Wednesday. But bringing the charges, the official said, was consistent with Mr. Obama’s belief that the United States needed to adopt tougher measures after President Xi Jinping brushed off Mr. Obama’s repeated demands that the Chinese government curb the hacking of American companies.

headline: EBay says client information stolen in hacking attack
abstract: EBay issues a notice on its websites asking users to change their passwords after discovering that a cyber attack compromised customer data earlier this year. Vanessa Johnston reports.
snippet: EBay issues a notice on its websites asking users to change their passwords after discovering that a cyber attack compromised customer data earlier this year. Vanessa Johnston reports.
lead_paragraph: EBay issues a notice on its websites asking users to change their passwords after discovering that a cyber attack compromised customer data earlier this year. Vanessa Johnston reports.

headline: EBay says client information stolen in hacking attack
abstract: EBay issues a notice on its websites asking users to change their passwords after discovering that a cyber attack compromised customer data earlier this year. Vanessa Johnston reports.
snippet: EBay issues a notice on its websites asking users to change their passwords after discovering that a cyber attack compromised customer data earlier this year. Vanessa Johnston reports.
lead_paragraph: EBay issues a notice on its websites asking users to change their passwords after discovering that a cyber attack compromised customer data earlier this year. Vanessa Johnston reports.

headline: Charges of Chinese Cyberspying, Wanted Posters Included
abstract: The five members of China’s military accused of hacking against American companies are at the top of the F.B.I. “Cyber’s Most Wanted” list, but little has been revealed about them beyond their names and aliases.
snippet: The five members of China’s military accused of hacking against American companies are at the top of the F.B.I. “Cyber’s Most Wanted” list, but little has been revealed about them beyond their names and aliases.
lead_paragraph: A United States indictment accusing members of China’s military of computer hacking against American companies has put a face on a practice the Obama administration has long complained of, the use of state cyberwarfare capabilities to steal corporate secrets. While little is publicly known about the five indicted members of the People’s Liberation Army, the F.B.I. has released photos and aliases of the men accused of being members of the Chinese military’s computer espionage Unit 61398, also known as the “Comment Crew.”

headline: Nuclear Talks Will Confront Iran’s Future Capability to Enrich Uranium
abstract: American negotiators say the key is to leave Iran with a face-saving nuclear structure but one small enough to overcome congressional objections.
snippet: American negotiators say the key is to leave Iran with a face-saving nuclear structure but one small enough to overcome congressional objections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Iran and six world powers meet this week in Vienna to begin drafting language to resolve their nuclear standoff, negotiators say they are finally confronting a crucial sticking point to a permanent agreement — the size and shape of the nuclear fuel production capability that Iran will be permitted to retain.

headline: Today in Small Business: Credit Cards for Small Businesses
abstract: Understanding why you are always so busy. Becoming a better negotiator. And introducing the “Zuckerberg tax.”
snippet: Understanding why you are always so busy. Becoming a better negotiator. And introducing the “Zuckerberg tax.”
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Hey, Jack, You’re Back! Anything New?
abstract: After a four-year hiatus, Jack Bauer and “24” are returning to Fox, but the show’s groundbreaking style now seems dated.
snippet: After a four-year hiatus, Jack Bauer and “24” are returning to Fox, but the show’s groundbreaking style now seems dated.
lead_paragraph: There is a Persian custom that could probably improve television.

headline: Summer Movie Release Schedule
abstract: Listings of this summer’s releases.
snippet: Listings of this summer’s releases.
lead_paragraph: Yes, Scarlett Johansson wakes up with superpowers and takes no prisoners, but the season isn’t totally about would-be action blockbusters. Philip Seymour Hoffman gifts us with two posthumous performances, as a blue-collar American loser and as a powerful German spy. Documentaries explore a dizzying range of topics, including legal marijuana, the war in Afghanistan, breast-feeding and the Koch brothers. And climate change rears its plot-driving head, ready to replace midcentury nuclear testing as the villain in sci-fi and futurist fantasies.

headline: White House Details Thinking on Cybersecurity Flaws
abstract: In a rare insight into the government’s thinking on the use of cyberweapons, the White House published a series of questions it asks in deciding when to make public the discovery of major flaws in computer security.
snippet: In a rare insight into the government’s thinking on the use of cyberweapons, the White House published a series of questions it asks in deciding when to make public the discovery of major flaws in computer security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rare insight into the government’s thinking on the use of cyberweapons, the White House on Monday published a series of questions it asks in deciding when to make public the discovery of major flaws in computer security or whether to keep them secret so that American intelligence agencies can use them to enable surveillance or an attack.

headline: Obama Lets N.S.A. Exploit Some Internet Flaws, Officials Say
abstract: The White House said that information about major Internet security flaws should be shared with computer and software manufacturers so they can be fixed. But it left broad exceptions for cases that involve national security.
snippet: The White House said that information about major Internet security flaws should be shared with computer and software manufacturers so they can be fixed. But it left broad exceptions for cases that involve national security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stepping into a heated debate within the nation’s intelligence agencies, President Obama has decided that when the National Security Agency discovers major flaws in Internet security, it should — in most circumstances — reveal them to assure that they will be fixed, rather than keep mum so that the flaws can be used in espionage or cyberattacks, senior administration officials said Saturday.

headline: 2 Regulators Issue Guidelines on Sharing Cyber Security Information
abstract: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission said that sharing information between companies about threats to cybersecurity is not likely to raise antitrust concerns.
snippet: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission said that sharing information between companies about threats to cybersecurity is not likely to raise antitrust concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Sharing information between companies about threats to cybersecurity is not likely to raise antitrust concerns, the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission said Thursday.

headline: Hagel Spars With Chinese Over Islands and Security
abstract: A dispute between Beijing and Tokyo has prompted Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel to warn that the United States would honor treaty obligations to defend its allies.
snippet: A dispute between Beijing and Tokyo has prompted Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel to warn that the United States would honor treaty obligations to defend its allies.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The United States and China clashed over Japan on Tuesday as the Chinese defense minister asserted that Beijing had “indisputable sovereignty” over a group of islands in the East China Sea and that his country’s military stood ready to protect its interests in territorial disputes.

headline: U.S. Tries Candor to Assure China on Cyberattacks
abstract: The U.S. held an unusual briefing for China on its cyberwarfare strategy in an effort to establish “an understanding of rules of the road.” So far, the Chinese have not reciprocated.
snippet: The U.S. held an unusual briefing for China on its cyberwarfare strategy in an effort to establish “an understanding of rules of the road.” So far, the Chinese have not reciprocated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the months before Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s arrival in Beijing on Monday, the Obama administration quietly held an extraordinary briefing for the Chinese military leadership on a subject officials have rarely discussed in public: the Pentagon’s emerging doctrine for defending against cyberattacks against the United States — and for using its cybertechnology against adversaries, including the Chinese.

headline: Hagel Seeks Peace Pact for Digital Realm
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said the U.S. does not seek to “militarize” cyberspace, and pledged the Pentagon would show restraint in its global operations — if other nations do the same.
snippet: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said the U.S. does not seek to “militarize” cyberspace, and pledged the Pentagon would show restraint in its global operations — if other nations do the same.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, in his first lengthy comments on the Pentagon’s growing mission in computer-network warfare, said Friday that the United States does not seek to “militarize” cyberspace, and pledged that the Defense Department would show restraint in its global operations — if other nations do the same.

headline: Recordings, Posted Online, Rattle Officials in Turkey
abstract: A recording was posted on YouTube in which officials were heard discussing a plot to establish a justification for military strikes in Syria.
snippet: A recording was posted on YouTube in which officials were heard discussing a plot to establish a justification for military strikes in Syria.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — If any meeting was meant to be private, it was this one: the top spy chief, the foreign minister and his deputy, and a top military official discussing secret plans for possible military action in Syria.

headline: A Failure for Citigroup
abstract: The Federal Reserve rejected Citigroup’s capital plans. | The chief executive of King Digital Entertainment remained optimistic after shares of his company fell nearly 16 percent on their first day of public trading. | Corporations are pressing law firms to tighten their cyber security. | Reverse mortgages are stinging heirs.
snippet: The Federal Reserve rejected Citigroup’s capital plans. | The chief executive of King Digital Entertainment remained optimistic after shares of his company fell nearly 16 percent on their first day of public trading. | Corporations are pressing la...
lead_paragraph: CITIGROUP FAILS FED STRESS TEST  |  For the second time in three years, the Federal Reserve rejected Citigroup’s plans to manage its capital, an embarrassing blow that could derail the plans of Michael Corbat, the bank’s chief executive, to rehabilitate the bank, Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. Citigroup was the only one of the nation’s top five banks that failed to persuade the Fed to bless its plans for shareholder payouts.

headline: Law Firms Are Pressed on Security for Data
abstract: Large American corporations are pressing their law firms to increase cyber security to deter hackers from gaining access to confidential information.
snippet: Large American corporations are pressing their law firms to increase cyber security to deter hackers from gaining access to confidential information.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of big corporate clients are demanding that their law firms take more steps to guard against online intrusions that could compromise sensitive information as global concerns about hacker threats mount.

headline: N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat
abstract: As the United States made a public case about the dangers of buying from Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, classified documents show that the National Security Agency was creating its own back doors — directly into Huawei’s networks.
snippet: As the United States made a public case about the dangers of buying from Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, classified documents show that the National Security Agency was creating its own back doors — directly into Huawei’s networks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials have long considered Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, a security threat, blocking it from business deals in the United States for fear that the company would create “back doors” in its equipment that could allow the Chinese military or Beijing-backed hackers to steal corporate and government secrets.

headline: Russia Seizes Gas Plant Near Crimea Border, Ukraine Says
abstract: On the eve of a secession referendum in Crimea, Russian forces took a natural gas terminal while Western officials prepared sanctions for Moscow.
snippet: On the eve of a secession referendum in Crimea, Russian forces took a natural gas terminal while Western officials prepared sanctions for Moscow.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Tensions mounted on the eve of a secession referendum here in Crimea as helicopter-borne Russian forces made a provocative incursion just outside the peninsula’s regional border to seize a natural gas terminal, while American and European officials prepared sanctions to impose on Moscow as early as Monday.

headline: Power Grid Preparedness Falls Short, Report Says
abstract: Almost every utility that participated in a test of the power grid’s defense against online and physical attacks said that their planning was not good enough.
snippet: Almost every utility that participated in a test of the power grid’s defense against online and physical attacks said that their planning was not good enough.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly all the utilities that participated in two-day exercise last November to test the preparedness of the power grid for online and physical attacks said that their planning was not good enough, according to a report by the North American Electric Reliability Corporation, which organized the drill.

headline: N.S.A. Nominee Promotes Cyberwar Units
abstract: Citing cyberattacks on the new Ukrainian government, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, said “cyber will be an element of every crisis.”
snippet: Citing cyberattacks on the new Ukrainian government, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, said “cyber will be an element of every crisis.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — All of the major combat commands in the United States military will soon have dedicated forces to conduct cyberattacks alongside their air, naval and ground capabilities, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, told the Senate on Tuesday. He said the activation of the long-discussed combat units would help counter the perception around the world that the United States is “an easier mark” for cyberattacks because it did not “have the will to respond.”

headline: Daunting Tests Await Admiral Named N.S.A. Chief
abstract: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, who currently runs the Navy’s Fleet Cyber Command, has been appointed to navigate a bureaucratic, political and public relations disaster.
snippet: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, who currently runs the Navy’s Fleet Cyber Command, has been appointed to navigate a bureaucratic, political and public relations disaster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is not hard to understand why veterans of the National Security Agency argue that 2013 was the worst year since Harry S. Truman got the place running 62 years ago.

headline: Suspicion Falls on Russia as ‘Snake’ Cyberattacks Target Ukraine’s Government
abstract: No one can quite pinpoint who is behind a series of cyberattacks that began long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, though some suspicion is falling on Russia.
snippet: No one can quite pinpoint who is behind a series of cyberattacks that began long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, though some suspicion is falling on Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since the first major protests in Kiev that triggered the current crisis with Moscow, American intelligence agencies have been on high alert for cyberattacks aimed at the new government in Ukraine. They were a bit late: the attacks started long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, and as might be expected, no one can quite pinpoint who is behind them, although some suspicion is falling on Russia.

headline: Stop Glorifying Hackers
abstract: Stealing my passwords doesn’t make you the Sundance Kid.
snippet: Stealing my passwords doesn’t make you the Sundance Kid.
lead_paragraph: I WAS at the Museum of Modern Art in New York not long ago, soaking in Edward Hopper’s retro downer mystique, when I got a call that opened up brave new all-night-diners of doom and gloom.

headline: Jail Sentence in France Over ‘Cyber Jihad’
abstract: A French convert to Islam was convicted of using the Internet to disseminate terrorist propaganda and promote participation in terrorist acts and was sentenced by a Paris court to one year in prison and two more on probation late Tuesday.
snippet: A French convert to Islam was convicted of using the Internet to disseminate terrorist propaganda and promote participation in terrorist acts and was sentenced by a Paris court to one year in prison and two more on probation late Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A French convert to Islam was convicted of using the Internet to disseminate terrorist propaganda and promote participation in terrorist acts and was sentenced by a Paris court to one year in prison and two more on probation late Tuesday. The case is the first using a law passed in 2012 that makes “cyber jihad” a crime and potentially has serious consequences for freedom of expression in France. The law was passed in response to the attacks in Toulouse by Mohammed Merah, who killed seven people including three children and apparently was inspired in part by extremist Internet postings. The maximum sentence in Tuesday’s case could have been five years in prison, and the relatively light term given to Romain Letellier, 27, suggested that both prosecutors and judges were still considering how to apply the new law. The prosecutor said that the trial was happening in a context where young people become radicalized rapidly after reading material on the Internet.

headline: N.S.A. Director Says Snowden Leaks Hamper Efforts Against Cyberattacks
abstract: Gen. Keith B. Alexander said the disclosures by Edward J. Snowden had slowed the push to protect the country against attacks on civilian targets.
snippet: Gen. Keith B. Alexander said the disclosures by Edward J. Snowden had slowed the push to protect the country against attacks on civilian targets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gen. Keith B. Alexander, the director of the National Security Agency, said Tuesday that the leaks by the former agency contractor Edward J. Snowden had slowed the effort to protect the country against cyberattacks on Wall Street and other civilian targets.

headline: Report Calls for Better Backstops to Protect Power Grid From Cyberattacks
abstract: The report, from leading security experts, also found that while the government has focused on the high-voltage power grid, less work has been done on the lower-voltage distribution system.
snippet: The report, from leading security experts, also found that while the government has focused on the high-voltage power grid, less work has been done on the lower-voltage distribution system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite rising anxiety over the possibility of a cyberattack on the power grid, the industry and government are not set up well to counter the threat, according to a report produced by leading energy security experts. Companies are reluctant to share information with one other, a critical step in reducing vulnerability, because they are afraid of being accused of failing to comply with cybersecurity rules, committing antitrust violations or giving away proprietary information, the report found.

headline: Powering up to fight electric grid cyber attacks
abstract: A new report from the Bipartisan Policy Center points out the vulnerabilities of the nation's utilities, and presents ideas to fight back. Bobbi Rebell reports.
snippet: A new report from the Bipartisan Policy Center points out the vulnerabilities of the nation's utilities, and presents ideas to fight back. Bobbi Rebell reports.
lead_paragraph: A new report from the Bipartisan Policy Center points out the vulnerabilities of the nation's utilities, and presents ideas to fight back. Bobbi Rebell reports.

headline: Bleak Houses
abstract: Denise Mina’s “Red Road” opens in 1997 with a shocking double murder in a seedy section of Glasgow.
snippet: Denise Mina’s “Red Road” opens in 1997 with a shocking double murder in a seedy section of Glasgow.
lead_paragraph: If anyone can make you root for the murderer, it’s Denise Mina, whose defiantly unsentimental novels are less concerned with personal guilt than with the social evils that create criminals and the predators who nurture them. THE RED ROAD (Little, Brown, $26), as fierce a story as any Mina has written, opens in 1997 with a shocking double murder in a seedy section of Glasgow. The murderer gives up without a fight, and that, you’d think, should be that — except for the fact that the killer, Rose Wilson, is a 14-year-old prostitute (“looking 16, feeling 12”) and one of the men she stabbed to death was the pimp who had hired her out to service eight men.

headline: Syria War Stirs New U.S. Debate on Cyberattacks
abstract: Considerations that led President Obama to hesitate about using cyberweapons against Syria reflect larger concerns about a new and untested tactic.
snippet: Considerations that led President Obama to hesitate about using cyberweapons against Syria reflect larger concerns about a new and untested tactic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after the uprising in Syria turned bloody, late in the spring of 2011, the Pentagon and the National Security Agency developed a battle plan that featured a sophisticated cyberattack on the Syrian military and President Bashar al-Assad’s command structure.

headline: Turks Protest New Internet Restrictions, in the Streets and Online
abstract: Turks took to the streets, and social networks, to protest new legislation that increases the government’s power to remove content from the web that might embarrass officials.
snippet: Turks took to the streets, and social networks, to protest new legislation that increases the government’s power to remove content from the web that might embarrass officials.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The police used force to disperse hundreds of Turks who gathered late Saturday to protest new legislation that increased government control of the Internet.

headline: Rare Afghan Polio Case Tied to Pakistan
abstract: Afghanistan is next door to Pakistan, where polio is much more widespread, and most of Afghanistan’s polio cases are traceable to that country.
snippet: Afghanistan is next door to Pakistan, where polio is much more widespread, and most of Afghanistan’s polio cases are traceable to that country.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A 3-year-old girl in Kabul has contracted polio, the first confirmed case in the capital in 12 years, health officials said Tuesday.

headline: Keeping Swindlers Out of Your Bank and Brokerage Accounts
abstract: Beyond employing offline common sense, individuals need to be vigilant about how they use technology and the systems their advisers have to prevent their accounts from being hacked.
snippet: Beyond employing offline common sense, individuals need to be vigilant about how they use technology and the systems their advisers have to prevent their accounts from being hacked.
lead_paragraph: Data breaches at Target and Neiman Marcus were certainly scary. Personal information from tens of millions of people fell into the hands of cybercriminals.

headline: N.S.A. Choice Is Navy Expert on Cyberwar
abstract: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, a cryptologist by training, will become the public face of the N.S.A. at a moment that it is caught in the cross hairs of a roiling debate.
snippet: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, a cryptologist by training, will become the public face of the N.S.A. at a moment that it is caught in the cross hairs of a roiling debate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In nominating Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers as the new director of the National Security Agency on Thursday, President Obama chose a recognized expert in the new art of designing cyberweapons, but someone with no public track record in addressing the kinds of privacy concerns that have put the agency under a harsh spotlight.

headline: Judge Limits Expert Testimony on Terrorism in Manhattan Bomb Case
abstract: The judge said he wanted to keep the focus on the evidence against Jose Pimentel, accused of plotting to set off pipe bombs, rather than on testimony about organizations and websites linked to Al Qaeda.
snippet: The judge said he wanted to keep the focus on the evidence against Jose Pimentel, accused of plotting to set off pipe bombs, rather than on testimony about organizations and websites linked to Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: Saying he wanted to avoid turning the trial into a “referendum on terrorism,” a state judge handling the case of a Manhattan man accused of planning pipe bombings said on Wednesday he sees no need for an expert on Islamic terrorism to testify at the defendant’s coming trial.

headline: Live Coverage of Obama’s 2014 State of the Union Address
abstract: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night and Times reporters and editors are providing analysis during the speech.
snippet: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night and Times reporters and editors are providing analysis during the speech.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night, and Times reporters and editors are providing analysis during the speech.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Letmein’
abstract: New York’s small businesses look to score with the Super Bowl. Where to find the world’s biggest tea drinkers. And a shortage of car-charging stations in Silicon Valley.
snippet: New York’s small businesses look to score with the Super Bowl. Where to find the world’s biggest tea drinkers. And a shortage of car-charging stations in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Obama’s Speech on N.S.A. Phone Surveillance
abstract: Following is the transcript of President Obama’s speech on National Security Agency data collection programs.
snippet: Following is the transcript of President Obama’s speech on National Security Agency data collection programs.
lead_paragraph: Following is the text of President Obama’s speech on National Security Agency data collection programs, as transcribed by the White House.

headline: Analysis of Obama’s N.S.A. Speech
abstract: President Obama delivered a much-anticipated speech Friday morning in which he announced that he is pulling back the government’s wide net of surveillance at home and abroad.
snippet: President Obama delivered a much-anticipated speech Friday morning in which he announced that he is pulling back the government’s wide net of surveillance at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered a much-anticipated speech Friday morning in which he announced that he is pulling back the government’s wide net of surveillance at home and abroad. Times reporters provided live analysis of the speech.

headline: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
abstract: The agency has put software in thousands of computers that allows for surveillance and can also create a path for launching cyberattacks, according to documents, experts and officials.
snippet: The agency has put software in thousands of computers that allows for surveillance and can also create a path for launching cyberattacks, according to documents, experts and officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has implanted software in nearly 100,000 computers around the world that allows the United States to conduct surveillance on those machines and can also create a digital highway for launching cyberattacks.

headline: S.E.C. Mired in Tensions Over Mortgage Cases
abstract: Internal tension at the S.E.C. raises questions about whether the agency could have done even more after the crisis to hold Wall Street accountable. | What the jurors in the Michael S. Steinberg case thought. | How real people hurt by the Stratton Oakmont scandal fared. | Ronald O. Perelman’s donation to the NYU Langone Medical Center.
snippet: Internal tension at the S.E.C. raises questions about whether the agency could have done even more after the crisis to hold Wall Street accountable. | What the jurors in the Michael S. Steinberg case thought. | How real people hurt by the Stratton...
lead_paragraph: |  TENSION AT S.E.C. OVER MORTGAGE CASES After months of investigating the role of Goldman Sachs, Wells Fargo and others in troubled mortgage securities — and even warning that enforcement actions were possible — the Securities and Exchange Commission shelved those cases and at least two others.

headline: A Legacy in the Balance on Surveillance Policies
abstract: At the heart of the report by a White House advisory group about America’s surveillance state is a challenge to President Obama’s conception of his presidency.
snippet: At the heart of the report by a White House advisory group about America’s surveillance state is a challenge to President Obama’s conception of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the proposed overhaul of the American surveillance state confronts him with a fundamental choice: Will he become the commander in chief many expected in 2008 or remain the one he became in 2009? Or is there a balance in between?

headline: Obama Weighing Security and Privacy in Deciding on Spy Program Limits
abstract: The president’s choices in the next few weeks may define America’s approach to national security long after his term is over.
snippet: The president’s choices in the next few weeks may define America’s approach to national security long after his term is over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If President Obama adopts the most far-reaching recommendations of the advisory group he set up to rein in the National Security Agency, much would change underneath the giant antennas that sprout over Fort Meade, Md., where America’s electronic spies and cyberwarriors have operated with an unprecedented amount of freedom since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: Obama Is Urged to Sharply Curb N.S.A. Data Mining
abstract: A panel of advisers urged President Obama to change the way the National Security Agency collects the telephone data of Americans, spies on foreign leaders and prepares for cyberattacks abroad.
snippet: A panel of advisers urged President Obama to change the way the National Security Agency collects the telephone data of Americans, spies on foreign leaders and prepares for cyberattacks abroad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A panel of outside advisers urged President Obama on Wednesday to impose major oversight and some restrictions on the National Security Agency, arguing that in the past dozen years its powers had been enhanced at the expense of personal privacy.

headline: Obama to Keep Security Agency and Cyberwarfare Under a Single Commander
abstract: The president made his choice despite concerns that it concentrates too much power in the hands of a single military official.
snippet: The president made his choice despite concerns that it concentrates too much power in the hands of a single military official.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has decided to keep the National Security Agency and the Pentagon’s cyberwarfare branch under the same command despite concerns that it concentrates too much power in the hands of a single military official responsible for both surveillance and directing a growing arsenal of cyberweapons.

headline: Obama Panel Said to Urge N.S.A. Curbs
abstract: A presidential advisory committee’s recommendation of broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections is a first sign that spying revelations may lead to changes.
snippet: A presidential advisory committee’s recommendation of broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections is a first sign that spying revelations may lead to changes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A presidential advisory committee charged with examining the operations of the National Security Agency has concluded that a program to collect data on every phone call made in the United States should continue, though under broad new restraints that would be intended to increase privacy protections, according to officials with knowledge of the report’s contents.

headline: Nick Kristof Answers Your Questions
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist responds to questions from readers on “Half the Sky”, Syria, China, and more.
snippet: The Op-Ed columnist responds to questions from readers on “Half the Sky”, Syria, China, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Monday readers were invited to ask Op-Ed columnist Nick Kristof questions on any topic. Dozens of readers asked Nick about subjects like the freedom of the press in China, President Obama’s second term agenda, whether the Middle East will ever have a Mandela-like figure, what he leaves out of his columns and more.

headline: Celebrity Lawyer Still Has the Skills
abstract: In “The Gods of Guilt,” Mickey Haller (a.k.a. the Lincoln Lawyer) has changed, but celebrity hasn’t gone to his head or his wallet.
snippet: In “The Gods of Guilt,” Mickey Haller (a.k.a. the Lincoln Lawyer) has changed, but celebrity hasn’t gone to his head or his wallet.
lead_paragraph: When we first met Michael Connelly’s Mickey Haller in “The Lincoln Lawyer” (2005), his shyster qualities were irresistible. He used his car as an office, advertised his services on bus benches in high-crime areas and bribed bail bondsmen with cans of Planters holiday nut mix filled with money. This last ploy gave Mickey untold business opportunities and let him eat a squirrel’s diet out of Tupperware until springtime. He was a refreshing change from his brooding, much older half-brother: Mr. Connelly’s best-known character, Hieronymus Bosch, a.k.a. Harry.

headline: Amazon Delivers Some Pie in the Sky
abstract: The plan announced by the company’s chief to use drone aircraft to deliver packages is visionary, far-fetched and loopy, as well as a useful distraction.
snippet: The plan announced by the company’s chief to use drone aircraft to deliver packages is visionary, far-fetched and loopy, as well as a useful distraction.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hard to believe, but there was once a time when the visionaries worked for the government. Rebuilding a ruined Europe, putting a man on the moon, ending poverty, connecting the American interior with highways — these were immense tasks undertaken, and often achieved, by bureaucrats.

headline: Walkabout: Mishaps in Pet Travel; Cyber Monday Travel Deals
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
snippet: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:58 a.m. | Not every pet travel story ends happily. One woman reports that her dog was diagnosed with heat stroke, a urinary tract infection and liver problems, following a United flight from Houston to Boston. (NBC Washington)

headline: Cyber Subterfuge
abstract: The Internet has lost its innocence: The virtual world is awash with espionage, malware and deception.
snippet: The Internet has lost its innocence: The virtual world is awash with espionage, malware and deception.
lead_paragraph: I awoke one morning to a disturbing email from the software giant Adobe. The message warned that thieves had hacked into the company’s servers, stolen the source code for some of its software products and almost three million passwords and credit card details, among which might be mine. It included a link to reset my password.

headline: Disruptions: A Digital Underworld Cloaked in Anonymity
abstract: Silk Road, a vast Internet black market, stands as a tabloid monument to old-fashioned vice and new-fashioned technology.
snippet: Silk Road, a vast Internet black market, stands as a tabloid monument to old-fashioned vice and new-fashioned technology.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — So this is where they collared the man they call the Dread Pirate Roberts.

headline: Attack Ravages Power Grid. (Just a Test.)
abstract: An unprecedented continental-scale war game was intended to determine how prepared the nation is for a cyberattack against electric systems.
snippet: An unprecedented continental-scale war game was intended to determine how prepared the nation is for a cyberattack against electric systems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In windowless rooms from here to California, nearly 10,000 electrical engineers, cybersecurity specialists, utility executives and F.B.I. agents furiously grappled over 48 hours with an unseen “enemy” who tried to turn out the lights across America. The enemy injected computer viruses into grid control systems, bombed transformers and substations and knocked out power lines by the dozen.

headline: New Chinese Panel Said to Oversee Domestic Security and Foreign Policy
abstract: China’s new national security committee, which is expected to be led by President Xi Jinping, will deal with cybersecurity, relations with Tibet and unrest in the Xinjiang region, Chinese experts say.
snippet: China’s new national security committee, which is expected to be led by President Xi Jinping, will deal with cybersecurity, relations with Tibet and unrest in the Xinjiang region, Chinese experts say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s new national security committee is mainly based on the Washington model. It will put at the disposal of the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, a highly empowered group of security experts who can work the levers of the country’s vast security apparatus — and presumably respond more nimbly than the country’s multilayered party, police and military bureaucracies have been known to do.

headline: U.S. Is Losing Advantage in Spying, Report Says
abstract: A congressional panel charged that the United States intelligence agencies’ research-and-development efforts were disorganized and unfocused.
snippet: A congressional panel charged that the United States intelligence agencies’ research-and-development efforts were disorganized and unfocused.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A congressional panel created long before the recent revelations about government electronic spying operations issued a blistering report on Tuesday charging that the intelligence world’s research-and-development efforts are disorganized and unfocused.

headline: Data Suggests Push to Spy on Merkel Dates to ’02
abstract: The administration has seemed uncertain about how to handle the reports concerning the German chancellor, who has enjoyed a close rapport with President Obama.
snippet: The administration has seemed uncertain about how to handle the reports concerning the German chancellor, who has enjoyed a close rapport with President Obama.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — New details about the monitoring of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphone by the National Security Agency further stoked the German government’s anger on Sunday and raised two questions: Why did the United States target her as early as 2002, and why did it take five years for the Obama administration to put a halt to the surveillance?

headline: When Is the Last Time You Did Something Nice for a Stranger?
abstract: Why do some people routinely pay for the food ordered by people in the car behind them at fast food drive-through windows?
snippet: Why do some people routinely pay for the food ordered by people in the car behind them at fast food drive-through windows?
lead_paragraph: Doing nice things for strangers isn’t something that just came about, but in recent years, “paying it forward” has become a trend.

headline: Ma’am, Your Burger Has Been Paid For
abstract: Drive on through. It’s taken care of.
snippet: Drive on through. It’s taken care of.
lead_paragraph: IF you place an order at the Chick-fil-A drive-through off Highway 46 in New Braunfels, Tex., it’s not unusual for the driver of the car in front of you to pay for your meal in the time it took you to holler into the intercom and pull around for pickup.

headline: Electrical Grid Is Called Vulnerable to Power Shutdown
abstract: The communications protocol used at many electric and water utilities may have flaws that some worry are not being fixed.
snippet: The communications protocol used at many electric and water utilities may have flaws that some worry are not being fixed.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few months, the discoveries of two engineers have led to a steady trickle of alarms from the Department of Homeland Security concerning a threat to the nation’s power grid. Yet hardly anyone has noticed.

headline: Beyond Babel, China’s Virtual Future
abstract: Chinese artists are using the Web as a grand canvas to create new landscapes, and even a language.
snippet: Chinese artists are using the Web as a grand canvas to create new landscapes, and even a language.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As the Internet becomes the main theater in a freedom of expression tug-of-war between China’s leadership and its citizens, it is also changing the ways some artists are conceiving their works — and even redefining Beijing’s cityscape.

headline: Bolstering a Phone’s Defenses Against Breaches
abstract: To help ward off corporate data breaches, Lookout is using its app to slip under the door of enterprises via the employees who regularly bring their personal devices to work.
snippet: To help ward off corporate data breaches, Lookout is using its app to slip under the door of enterprises via the employees who regularly bring their personal devices to work.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — From Lookout’s headquarters here, the view extends west from the Bay Bridge to the Golden Gate, but its employees — mostly 20-something engineers in T-shirts and jeans — seem too preoccupied with the world’s nastiest new threats to take it in.

headline: N.S.A. Director Firmly Defends Surveillance Efforts
abstract: While acknowledging shortfalls in response to Edward J. Snowden’s revelations, General Keith B. Alexander said the agency was doing more “to protect people’s civil liberties and privacy than they’ll ever know.”
snippet: While acknowledging shortfalls in response to Edward J. Snowden’s revelations, General Keith B. Alexander said the agency was doing more “to protect people’s civil liberties and privacy than they’ll ever know.”
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The director of the National Security Agency, Gen. Keith B. Alexander, said in an interview that to prevent terrorist attacks he saw no effective alternative to the N.S.A.’s bulk collection of telephone and other electronic metadata from Americans. But he acknowledged that his agency now faced an entirely new reality, and the possibility of Congressional restrictions, after revelations about its operations at home and abroad.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.
snippet: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Budget Documents Detail Extent of U.S. Cyberoperations
abstract: The documents show that the United States conducted 231 cyberoperations in 2011, even while the Obama administration protested other countries’ attacks on American computer networks.
snippet: The documents show that the United States conducted 231 cyberoperations in 2011, even while the Obama administration protested other countries’ attacks on American computer networks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Newly disclosed budget documents for America’s intelligence agencies show how aggressively the United States is now conducting offensive cyberoperations against other nations, even as the Obama administration protests attacks on American computer networks by China, Iran and Russia.

headline: The ‘Black Budget,’ Revealed
abstract: Why are intelligence agency budgets classified? Is the government worried about national security, or the accountability that comes with disclosure?
snippet: Why are intelligence agency budgets classified? Is the government worried about national security, or the accountability that comes with disclosure?
lead_paragraph: For budget-watchers, it was a voyeuristic thrill to read through the Washington Post’s article today exposing the secret details of the intelligence community’s “black budget.” The world now knows that the C.I.A. gets the biggest chunk of intelligence spending at $14.7 billion for 2013, and that a little-known agency, the National Reconnaissance Office, gets $10.3 billion, almost as much as the National Security Agency. (The reconnaissance office builds spy satellites, which are apparently rather pricey.)

headline: N.S.A. Leaks Make Plan for Cyberdefense Unlikely
abstract: The National Security Agency has lobbied to deploy a “Star Wars” defense for America’s computer networks, but officials said the plan had little chance of moving forward.
snippet: The National Security Agency has lobbied to deploy a “Star Wars” defense for America’s computer networks, but officials said the plan had little chance of moving forward.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even while rapidly expanding its electronic surveillance around the world, the National Security Agency has lobbied inside the government to deploy the equivalent of a “Star Wars” defense for America’s computer networks, designed to intercept cyberattacks before they could cripple power plants, banks or financial markets.

headline: Wall Street’s Exposure to Hacking Laid Bare
abstract: Five people were accused of hacking into the servers of major companies and Nasdaq, showing the vulnerability of some computer systems.
snippet: Five people were accused of hacking into the servers of major companies and Nasdaq, showing the vulnerability of some computer systems.
lead_paragraph: The indictment on Thursday of a long-running hacking ring is kindling fears that rogue programmers are going beyond theft and developing the capacity to wreak havoc on the broader financial system.

headline: Leap Motion Controller, Great Hardware in Search of Great Software
abstract: The controller promises to let you control your computer with hand motions, and the hardware does that, but its software is scattershot, inconsistent and frustrating.
snippet: The controller promises to let you control your computer with hand motions, and the hardware does that, but its software is scattershot, inconsistent and frustrating.
lead_paragraph: By now, we all know what the future will be like; movies and TV shows have described it in detail. We know about the flying cars (thank you, “Blade Runner”), holograms (thank you, “Star Trek”) and robot butlers (thank you, “Jetsons”).

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Secret Service Sells Fake IDs and Exes in Texts
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selections feature an odd tale of how the Secret Service established and operated a counterfeiting factory to catch cyber criminals, and an essay about why the social media generation never really breaks up with one another.
snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selections feature an odd tale of how the Secret Service established and operated a counterfeiting factory to catch cyber criminals...
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Encryption Flaw Makes Phones Possible Accomplices in Theft
abstract: A German mobile security expert says he has found a flaw in the encryption technology used in some SIM cards that could enable cyber criminals to take control of a person’s phone.
snippet: A German mobile security expert says he has found a flaw in the encryption technology used in some SIM cards that could enable cyber criminals to take control of a person’s phone.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — If your identity has been stolen, your phone may have been an accomplice to the crime.

headline: N.S.A. Imposes Rules to Protect Secret Data Stored on Its Networks
abstract: The new mission formalizes America’s use of a class of weapons that the Obama administration has rarely discussed in public.
snippet: The new mission formalizes America’s use of a class of weapons that the Obama administration has rarely discussed in public.
lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — The National Security Agency has imposed new rules designed to sharply restrict the sharing and downloading of top-secret material from its computer networks after a review of how Edward J. Snowden, a former agency contractor, managed to expose several of the country’s most sensitive surveillance programs, two of the Pentagon’s most senior officials said Thursday.

headline: Résumé Shows Snowden Honed Hacking Skills
abstract: Edward J. Snowden’s résumé suggests that he transformed himself into the kind of cybersecurity expert the National Security Agency is desperate to recruit.
snippet: Edward J. Snowden’s résumé suggests that he transformed himself into the kind of cybersecurity expert the National Security Agency is desperate to recruit.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, while working for a National Security Agency contractor, Edward J. Snowden learned to be a hacker.

headline: Job Title Key to Inner Access Held by Snowden
abstract: Edward J. Snowden’s assignment as an “infrastructure analyst” helps explain how he could lay bare the National Security Agency’s efforts to identify potential targets.
snippet: Edward J. Snowden’s assignment as an “infrastructure analyst” helps explain how he could lay bare the National Security Agency’s efforts to identify potential targets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officials refer to Edward J. Snowden’s job as a National Security Agency contractor as “systems administrator” — a bland name for the specialists who keep the computers humming. But his last job before leaking classified documents about N.S.A. surveillance, he told the news organization The Guardian, was actually “infrastructure analyst.”

headline: Pentagon Is Updating Conflict Rules in Cyberspace
abstract: The United States is looking for ways to improve its defenses and increase the nimbleness of its response in case of computer-network attacks.
snippet: The United States is looking for ways to improve its defenses and increase the nimbleness of its response in case of computer-network attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is updating its classified rules for warfare in cyberspace for the first time in seven years, an acknowledgment of the growing threat posed by computer-network attacks — and the need for the United States to improve its defenses and increase the nimbleness of its response, the nation’s top military officer said Thursday.

headline: June 23 Updates on Snowden’s Asylum Pursuit
abstract: reporting snowden’s whereabouts
snippet: reporting snowden’s whereabouts
lead_paragraph: Two days after the United States charged him with espionage, Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has admitted to disclosing classified information about the country’s government surveillance programs, left Hong Kong and is now seeking asylum in Ecuador, the foreign minister of Ecuador posted on Twitter. As our colleagues Keith Bradsher and Ellen Barry report, Mr. Snowden took a flight to Moscow, where he remained at the airport on Sunday. The Lede will be providing live updates.

headline: Web’s Reach Binds N.S.A. and Silicon Valley Leaders
abstract: Technology experts and former intelligence officials say the rise of data mining, both as an industry and as a crucial intelligence tool, has created a complex reality.
snippet: Technology experts and former intelligence officials say the rise of data mining, both as an industry and as a crucial intelligence tool, has created a complex reality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Max Kelly, the chief security officer for Facebook, left the social media company in 2010, he did not go to Google, Twitter or a similar Silicon Valley concern. Instead the man who was responsible for protecting the personal information of Facebook’s more than one billion users from outside attacks went to work for another giant institution that manages and analyzes large pools of data: the National Security Agency.

headline: How Cyberwarfare and Drones Have Revolutionized Warfare
abstract: Tim Hsia and Jared Sperli write that the next few decades will be dominated by advancements in software and hardware (cyber and robotics, including drones) just as the last decade was dominated by counterinsurgency.
snippet: Tim Hsia and Jared Sperli write that the next few decades will be dominated by advancements in software and hardware (cyber and robotics, including drones) just as the last decade was dominated by counterinsurgency.
lead_paragraph: Since World War II there have been many advances in military weaponry, communications and technology. In early May 1942, naval forces from Imperial Japan and the allied forces of Australia and the United States fought in the Battle of the Coral Sea. That engagement was the first battle in which naval ships did not shoot upon or even see the opposing force. Aircraft carriers directly engaged one another using aircraft, with their long-distance reach, as their sole offensive weaponry. This new type of warfare, the carrier versus carrier, was an inevitable escalation of the air, radio and radar technology of the day. It was viewed as a revolution in military affairs.

headline: After Profits, Defense Contractor Faces the Pitfalls of Cybersecurity
abstract: Mike McConnell, who once led the National Security Agency, is now the chief architect of Booz Allen’s cyberstrategy — and among the executives facing tough questions after a data leak.
snippet: Mike McConnell, who once led the National Security Agency, is now the chief architect of Booz Allen’s cyberstrategy — and among the executives facing tough questions after a data leak.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the United Arab Emirates wanted to create its own version of the National Security Agency, it turned to Booz Allen Hamilton to replicate the world’s largest and most powerful spy agency in the sands of Abu Dhabi.

headline: A Promise of Changes for Access to Secrets
abstract: The chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said Thursday that Congress would consider legislation to sharply limit the access that private contractors have to the nation’s most sensitive intelligence programs.
snippet: The chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said Thursday that Congress would consider legislation to sharply limit the access that private contractors have to the nation’s most sensitive intelligence programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee emerged from a classified briefing on Thursday about the leak of top secret surveillance programs and declared that Congress would soon consider legislation to sharply limit the access that private contractors — who operate much of the national security infrastructure — have to the nation’s most sensitive intelligence programs.

headline: Can N.S.A. Surveillance Be Likened to Chinese Spying?
abstract: Amid a report that the N.S.A. gathered communications from China, state media have begun to speak out; others ask if gathering commercial and military secrets, and surveillance to stop terrorist attacks, can even be likened.
snippet: Amid a report that the N.S.A. gathered communications from China, state media have begun to speak out; others ask if gathering commercial and military secrets, and surveillance to stop terrorist attacks, can even be likened.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING —“Snowden: American Government Invaded Chinese Computers,” ran a headline Thursday on CCTV, China’s state-run television channel.

headline: N.S.A. Chief Says Phone Logs Halted Terror Threats
abstract: Gen. Keith B. Alexander told Congress that “dozens” of attacks were prevented in the United States and abroad, and that  “what we’re doing to protect American citizens here is the right thing.”
snippet: Gen. Keith B. Alexander told Congress that “dozens” of attacks were prevented in the United States and abroad, and that  “what we’re doing to protect American citizens here is the right thing.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The director of the National Security Agency told Congress on Wednesday that “dozens” of terrorism threats had been halted by the agency’s huge database of the logs of nearly every domestic phone call made by Americans, while a senator briefed on the program disclosed that the telephone records are destroyed after five years.

headline: U.S. Helps Allies Trying to Battle Iranian Hackers

snippet: The administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build their defenses against Iran’s cyberweapons and will do the same in Asia to contain attacks from North Korea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build up their defenses against Iran’s growing arsenal of cyberweapons, and will be doing the same in Asia to contain computer-network attacks from North Korea, according to senior American officials.
