snippet: President Obama on Friday defended government efforts to gather telephone and Internet data, and sought to reassure Americans that his administration was not listening in on their calls.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama offered a robust defense of newly revealed surveillance programs on Friday as more classified secrets spilled into public, complicating a summit meeting with China’s new president focused partly on human rights and cybersecurity.

headline: Leaks Overshadow Obama’s Meeting With President of China
abstract: The meeting with President Xi Jinping was expected to be a venue for Mr. Obama to raise concerns about Chinese cyber attacks and spying. Now, it will take place amid striking revelations about the United States’s surveillance of its own citizens.
snippet: The meeting with President Xi Jinping was expected to be a venue for Mr. Obama to raise concerns about Chinese cyber attacks and spying. Now, it will take place amid striking revelations about the United States’s surveillance of its own citizens.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — New disclosures about top-secret government programs to collect data on Americans’ phone calls and Internet activity are likely to overshadow President Obama’s two-day summit this weekend with the president of China.

headline: Better Late Than Never on Deeming Nonbanks Too Big to Fail
abstract: Still, in designating A.I.G. and GE Capital systemically important, regulators show they are stuck for the most part in the last crisis rather than looking out for the next one, the author contends.
snippet: Still, in designating A.I.G. and GE Capital systemically important, regulators show they are stuck for the most part in the last crisis rather than looking out for the next one, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: New systemic-risk tags are better late than never. The American International Group, GE Capital and Prudential Financial are among the first nonbank firms to be deemed systemically important financial institutions by the Financial Stability Oversight Council. These are no-brainers for the moniker. The trouble is, five years on, watchdogs are still bogged down in the last crisis rather than looking out for the next one.

headline: U.S. and China Agree to Hold Regular Talks on Hacking
abstract: The United States hopes the dialogue can help set norms and end what it says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets by Chinese hackers.
snippet: The United States hopes the dialogue can help set norms and end what it says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets by Chinese hackers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and China have agreed to hold regular, high-level talks on how to set standards of behavior for cybersecurity and commercial espionage, the first diplomatic effort to defuse the tensions over what the United States says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets.

headline: Swindles and Spam, Lurking in Your Search Results

snippet: A little caution when using a search engine can help you steer clear of fraudulent merchandise and keep out of the clutches of spammers.
lead_paragraph: Most of our ventures onto the Web still begin with a search — a fact readily exploited by spammers and swindlers who rely on excessive use of keywords, link exchanging and other manipulation techniques to push their content higher in the list of search results, hoping you will click on them.

headline: White House Sets U.S.-China Summit for California in June

headline: Cyberattacks Against U.S. Corporations Are on the Rise

snippet: Officials said the aim in a new wave of attacks was not espionage but sabotage, and that the source seemed to be in the Middle East.

This time, officials say, the attackers’ aim is not espionage but sabotage, and the source seems to be somewhere in the Middle East.

snippet: The authorities said laptops and the Internet were used in more than two dozen countries to steal from A.T.M.’s, including 2,904 machines in New York City, in one day.

snippet: Computer espionage is growing ever more dangerous, and Washington directly blames Beijing of mounting attacks.

abstract: Online security has come to mean protecting our entire way of life.
snippet: Online security has come to mean protecting our entire way of life.
lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — The changes in the digital world today represent a dramatically sped-up version of the changes the world underwent in a century of industrialization. It is a paradigm transformation of our world: Notions of a nation’s size, wealth, power, military might, population and G.D.P. mean something altogether different from what they meant a generation ago.

When friends weren’t looking, he slipped his program onto their computers. It was all fun and games until the program spread to his middle school.

headline: What’s on Sunday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 55TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS L L Cool J returns as host of this ceremony honoring artists in country, hip-hop, jazz, pop and rock and broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. The group Fun. (including Nate Ruess, above left, with Jack Antonoff); Jay-Z; Mumford & Sons; Frank Ocean; and Kanye West lead the pack with six nominations each. Miguel and the Black Keys have five. Zac Brown, Brittany Howard of the Alabama Shakes, Elton John, Mumford & Sons and Mavis Staples will pay tribute to Levon Helm, who died in April, with a performance directed by T Bone Burnett. Dr. John, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, the Black Keys, Stanley Clarke, Chick Corea and Kenny Garrett will honor Dave Brubeck, who died in December. Justin Timberlake, Alicia Keys, Maroon 5, Frank Ocean, Carly Rae Jepsen, Katy Perry, Rihanna, Bruno Mars, Sting, Taylor Swift, the Lumineers, Carrie Underwood and Jack White are expected to perform. Red carpet coverage begins at 5 on E! and TV Guide.

One by one, they stood in front of the room and exhibited their “bug-out bags,” meticulously packed receptacles filled with equipment meant to see them through the collapse of civilization.

headline: Security Firm Discovers Cyber-Spy Campaign
abstract: A Russian cybersecurity company issued a report on Monday saying that it had identified a sophisticated cyberespionage campaign that has been in operation since 2007. The spy campaign has targeted a range of government and diplomatic organizations, mostly in Eastern Europe, and evidence suggests the attackers are of Russian-speaking origin.
snippet: A Russian cybersecurity company issued a report on Monday saying that it had identified a sophisticated cyberespionage campaign that has been in operation since 2007. The spy campaign has targeted a range of government and diplomatic organizations...
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A Russian cybersecurity company issued a report on Monday saying that it had identified a sophisticated cyberespionage campaign that has been in operation since 2007. The spy campaign targeted a range of government and diplomatic organizations, mostly in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, but also in Western Europe and North America.

headline: Serious Flaw in Java Software Is Found, Then Patched
abstract: The vulnerability was serious enough for the Department of Homeland Security to advise all users of Microsoft Windows, Apple’s Mac OS X and Linux platforms to disable Java in their Web browsers.
snippet: The vulnerability was serious enough for the Department of Homeland Security to advise all users of Microsoft Windows, Apple’s Mac OS X and Linux platforms to disable Java in their Web browsers.
lead_paragraph: 6:53 p.m. | Updated Oracle fixed a security flaw in its Java software on Sunday, after the Department of Homeland Security warned users to disable Java software completely, citing a security hole that allows hackers to take control of their machines.

headline: Wells Fargo Kicks Off Bank Earnings
abstract: Wells Fargo announces earnings Thursday morning, amid signs that the housing market may be beginning a recovery. | The settlement this week with 10 big banks ends a foreclosure review process that was deeply flawed. | The models regulators use to assess risk may be useful during normal times, but not when they matter the most, a federal agency said. | Herbalife sought on Thursday to counter accusations that the company was a fraud, but investors were still making up their minds.
snippet: Wells Fargo announces earnings Thursday morning, amid signs that the housing market may be beginning a recovery. | The settlement this week with 10 big banks ends a foreclosure review process that was deeply flawed. | The models regulators use to ...
lead_paragraph: WELLS FARGO KICKS OFF BANK EARNINGS  |  Investors are gearing up for the latest round of bank earnings reports, after a sluggish year for Wall Street. Wells Fargo announces results at 8 a.m. with a conference call set for 10 a.m. Analysts are expecting fourth-quarter earnings of 89 cents a share, an improvement over the period a year earlier, amid signs that the housing market may be beginning a recovery. Still, Wells Fargo’s net interest margin, the difference between what the bank charges borrowers and pays depositors, has fallen in recent quarters.

headline: Cyberstalkers Threaten Pipeline Security
abstract: In fiscal 2012, the energy sector was the target of around 40 percent of cybersecurity threats to the nation’s infrastructure.
snippet: In fiscal 2012, the energy sector was the target of around 40 percent of cybersecurity threats to the nation’s infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: In a recent  annual review, a team at the Department of Homeland Security that works to counter  the threat of attacks  on critical computer infrastructure counted 198 incidents in fiscal 2012. The events reported ranged from the use of malware to sabotage systems to phishing attacks for retrieving  sensitive information. In roughly 40 percent of those cases, the target was the energy sector – “an alarming rate,” the report said.

headline: Bank Hacking Was the Work of Iranians, Officials Say
abstract: The skill required to execute the attacks convinced American officials that Iran was behind them, likely in retaliation for economic sanctions and online attacks by the United States.
snippet: The skill required to execute the attacks convinced American officials that Iran was behind them, likely in retaliation for economic sanctions and online attacks by the United States.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The attackers hit one American bank after the next. As in so many previous attacks, dozens of online banking sites slowed, hiccupped or ground to a halt before recovering several minutes later.

headline: Hagel on Key Issues
abstract: Chuck Hagel, a Republican from Nebraska, was elected to the Senate in 1996 and retired in 2008. Following are some of his recent statements on issues he is likely to confront if he is confirmed as secretary of defense.

headline: India’s Rape and Sexual Assault Laws Under Scrutiny
abstract: Outdated concepts like “outraging the modesty of a woman” and unclear guidelines about punishment need to be changed, activists say.
snippet: Outdated concepts like “outraging the modesty of a woman” and unclear guidelines about punishment need to be changed, activists say.
lead_paragraph: The death of a young rape victim in from Delhi has reopened a debate in India about the country’s sexual assault and rape laws, as sweeping changes are being demanded to improve women’s rights in the country.

headline: U.S. Banks Again Hit by Wave of Cyberattacks
abstract: For the last week, hackers struck the Web sites of several American banks with so-called denial of service attacks. The attacks appear to be the second wave of a hacking campaign that began in September, when a hacker group calling itself Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Cyber Fighters took credit for a series of attacks on banking sites in retaliation for an anti-Islam video that was posted online in the United States.
snippet: For the last week, hackers struck the Web sites of several American banks with so-called denial of service attacks. The attacks appear to be the second wave of a hacking campaign that began in September, when a hacker group calling itself Izz ad-D...
lead_paragraph: For the last week, hackers have — once again — attacked the online banking sites of several American banks.

headline: Iran Suggests Attacks on Computer Systems Came From the U.S. and Israel
abstract: Foreign enemy hackers were blamed for attempts at disrupting systems in a strategically important southern coastal province.
snippet: Foreign enemy hackers were blamed for attempts at disrupting systems in a strategically important southern coastal province.
lead_paragraph: Iran reported a number of new cyberattacks on Tuesday, saying foreign enemy hackers tried in recent months to disrupt computer systems at a power plant and other industries in a strategically important southern coastal province as well as at a Culture Ministry information center.

headline: Study May Offer Insight Into Coca-Cola Breach
abstract: A 2010 case study of a security breach at an unnamed Fortune 500 company appears to offers new details of a breach at Coca-Cola.
snippet: A 2010 case study of a security breach at an unnamed Fortune 500 company appears to offers new details of a breach at Coca-Cola.
lead_paragraph: Spend enough time with cybersecurity experts and chances are you will hear some variation of this line: There are two types of companies in the United States, those that have been hacked and those that don’t yet know they’ve been hacked.

headline: Internet Shutdown Reported Across Syria
abstract: Internet access disappeared across Syria on Thursday, and airports were closed, prompting antigovernment activists to warn that the authorities might be planning to escalate their crackdown.
snippet: Internet access disappeared across Syria on Thursday, and airports were closed, prompting antigovernment activists to warn that the authorities might be planning to escalate their crackdown.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:37 p.m. Internet access disappeared across Syria on Thursday, and commercial air traffic was halted, prompting antigovernment activists to warn that the authorities might be planning to escalate their crackdown against the country’s raging uprising. Only residents with their own satellite connections to the Internet could access the Web, activists said. Disruptions to phone service were also reported.

headline: Cyber Attacks From Iran and Gaza on Israel More Threatening Than Anonymous’s Efforts
abstract: Anonymous has put forth tens of millions of hacking efforts on Israeli government sites and businesses in the last week, intermittently knocking hundreds offline, defacing some and erasing the databases for others. But compared with other recent cyber attacks on Israeli targets, the Anonymous efforts are a minor annoyance.
snippet: Anonymous has put forth tens of millions of hacking efforts on Israeli government sites and businesses in the last week, intermittently knocking hundreds offline, defacing some and erasing the databases for others. But compared with other recent c...
lead_paragraph: Anonymous, the loose coalition of hackers waging war on Israeli Web sites, is the least of Israel’s cyber problems. Its campaign against Israel is a minor annoyance compared with a wave of cyber attacks that have hit the country over the last year from Iran and Gaza.

headline: A Need for Clearer Disclosure Rules after Cyberattacks
abstract: Regulators need to provide clearer guidance on cyberattack disclosure to help companies address the often competing obligations to law enforcement and their investors, the authors write.
snippet: Regulators need to provide clearer guidance on cyberattack disclosure to help companies address the often competing obligations to law enforcement and their investors, the authors write.
lead_paragraph: Craig A. Newman and Daniel L. Stein are litigation partners with Richards Kibbe & Orbe, the New York-based law firm. Mr. Newman also serves as chief executive of the Freedom2Connect Foundation, a nonprofit group focused on promoting Internet freedom through the use of technology. Mr. Stein is a former federal prosecutor.

headline: Employee Charged in Plot to Bomb Home Depots
abstract: The man, Daniel Patrick Sheehan, 50, laid out his demands in a pair of ransom letters and anonymous phone calls to company representatives last month.
snippet: The man, Daniel Patrick Sheehan, 50, laid out his demands in a pair of ransom letters and anonymous phone calls to company representatives last month.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island man planted a pipe bomb inside a Home Depot store as part of a $2 million extortion plot, threatening to detonate similar devices in three stores on a major shopping day if he was not paid off, federal prosecutors said Thursday.

headline: Carmen Basilio Dies at 85; Took Title From Robinson
abstract: Mr. Basilio stepped up a weight class when he beat Sugar Ray Robinson in a split decision for his middleweight crown in 1957 at Yankee Stadium, but lost to him in 1958.
snippet: Mr. Basilio stepped up a weight class when he beat Sugar Ray Robinson in a split decision for his middleweight crown in 1957 at Yankee Stadium, but lost to him in 1958.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Basilio, the welterweight and middleweight boxing champion of the 1950s who fought two brutal bouts with Sugar Ray Robinson, winning his middleweight title and then losing it to him, died on Wednesday in Rochester. Basilio, who lived in Irondequoit, a suburb of Rochester, was 85.

headline: Killing the Computer to Save It
abstract: Dr. Neumann, an 80-year-old computer scientist at SRI International, is leading an effort to redesign computers and software from a “clean slate” to make them more secure.
snippet: Dr. Neumann, an 80-year-old computer scientist at SRI International, is leading an effort to redesign computers and software from a “clean slate” to make them more secure.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Many people cite Albert Einstein’s aphorism “Everything should be made as simple as possible, but no simpler.” Only a handful, however, have had the opportunity to discuss the concept with the physicist over breakfast.

headline: Daily Report: How Aramco Got Hacked
abstract: How hackers unleashed a computer virus that destroyed data on three-quarters of the PCs of the oil giant Saudi Aramco. American officials believe Iran was behind the attack.
snippet: How hackers unleashed a computer virus that destroyed data on three-quarters of the PCs of the oil giant Saudi Aramco. American officials believe Iran was behind the attack.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 15, more than 55,000 Saudi Aramco employees stayed home from work to prepare for one of Islam’s holiest nights of the year — Lailat al Qadr, or the Night of Power — celebrating the revelation of the Koran to Muhammad.

headline: In Cyberattack on Saudi Firm, U.S. Sees Iran Firing Back
abstract: American officials believe a virus unleashed on an oil giant was a return volley in a conflict begun by the United States and Israel with software that targeted Iran’s centrifuges.
snippet: American officials believe a virus unleashed on an oil giant was a return volley in a conflict begun by the United States and Israel with software that targeted Iran’s centrifuges.
lead_paragraph: The hackers picked the one day of the year they knew they could inflict the most damage on the world’s most valuable company, Saudi Aramco.

headline: The Internet Attack That Wasn’t
abstract: On Monday, a popular security blogger sent out an alert that the entire Web might be under attack. As it turned out, the Internet was just undergoing the digital version of a fire drill.
snippet: On Monday, a popular security blogger sent out an alert that the entire Web might be under attack. As it turned out, the Internet was just undergoing the digital version of a fire drill.
lead_paragraph: For an hour Monday afternoon, the entire Internet came under attack. Or so it seemed.

headline: For Fair Elections
abstract: Something extraordinary happened in Russia this weekend: an opposition movement that began less than a year ago managed to hold a fair election.
snippet: Something extraordinary happened in Russia this weekend: an opposition movement that began less than a year ago managed to hold a fair election.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Late Sunday evening I walked down to Trubnaya Square in central Moscow. It was cordoned off, as it had been for two days; several police buses were parked nearby — down from dozens earlier in the day. Clumps of people crowded at two large white tents. The stage at one end of the square was lit but empty. 1980s music popular with the protest crowd continued to blare.

headline: Disruptions: A Tiny Camera for the Stratosphere
abstract: While the smartphone has pushed some camera companies off a cliff, a tiny, ultrahigh-resolution camera that can record that very feat has taken off into the stratosphere, figuratively and literally.
snippet: While the smartphone has pushed some camera companies off a cliff, a tiny, ultrahigh-resolution camera that can record that very feat has taken off into the stratosphere, figuratively and literally.
lead_paragraph: There have been two major milestones in narcissistic photography in the last century. The first was the invention of the self-timer, which Kodak began selling during World War I. The second came a few years ago, as teenagers stood at mirrors taking pictures of themselves with camera phones to share online.

headline: U.S. Suspects Iran Was Behind a Wave of Cyberattacks
abstract: Intelligence officials believe network attacks that crippled computers across the Saudi oil industry and breached American financial institutions originated in Iran.
snippet: Intelligence officials believe network attacks that crippled computers across the Saudi oil industry and breached American financial institutions originated in Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence officials are increasingly convinced that Iran was the origin of a serious wave of network attacks that crippled computers across the Saudi oil industry and breached financial institutions in the United States, episodes that contributed to a warning last week from Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta that the United States was at risk of a “cyber-Pearl Harbor.”

headline: The Dangers of Allowing an Adversary Access to a Network

headline: In Cyberattacks on Banks, Evidence of a New Weapon
abstract: Last week, a group claiming Middle Eastern ties claimed to have taken down the Web sites of several American banks using amateur attack tools. Security researchers discovered that the hackers never used the tools they claimed. Instead, they did something much more troublesome: They infected data servers all over the world with a particularly form of malware that eludes antivirus systems and be used in a potentially more harmful attack another day.

lead_paragraph: How were amateur hackers able to take down some of America’s largest banks?  And who were they?

headline: 300,000 Android ‘Phones’ Roam a Virtual Town

headline: Cyberwarfare Emerges From Shadows for Public Discussion by U.S. Officials
abstract: The federal government’s announcement of a program to enlist contractors to develop technology is seen as a turning point in a long-secret program.
snippet: The federal government’s announcement of a program to enlist contractors to develop technology is seen as a turning point in a long-secret program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, even as the United States carried out sophisticated cyberattacks on Iran’s nuclear program and the Pentagon created a Cyber Command, officials have been hesitant to discuss American offensive cyberwarfare programs openly. Since June, in fact, F.B.I. agents have been investigating leaks to The New York Times about the computer attacks on Tehran.

headline: American Banks Undamaged by Cyberattacks
abstract: Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, U.S. Bancorp and PNC have been hit by cyberattacks that have caused Internet blackouts and delays to online banking sites by a group claiming Middle Eastern ties. The attacks, while a nuisance, were not technically sophisticated and did not affect companies’ computer network or funds, or customers’ bank accounts.
snippet: Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, U.S. Bancorp and PNC have been hit by cyberattacks that have caused Internet blackouts and delays to online banking sites by a group claiming Middle Eastern ties. The attacks, while a nuisance, were not ...

headline: Mitt and Bibi: Diplomacy as Demolition Derby
abstract: A review of the latest foreign policy missteps of Bibi Netanyahu and Mitt Romney in the Middle East.
snippet: A review of the latest foreign policy missteps of Bibi Netanyahu and Mitt Romney in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: It turns out Bibi Netanyahu and Mitt Romney have more in common than a background in management consulting and an unswerving devotion to the security of Israel. When it comes to international diplomacy, we are reminded this week, both have the subtle grace of cattle on loco weed.

headline: GoDaddy Goes Down, and a Hacker Takes Credit
abstract: A supporter of Anonymous, the loose hacking collective, claimed responsibility for an attack that apparently brought down Web sites hosted by Go Daddy. The company’s site was down Monday afternoon, as were many of the Web sites hosted on its servers.
snippet: A supporter of Anonymous, the loose hacking collective, claimed responsibility for an attack that apparently brought down Web sites hosted by Go Daddy. The company’s site was down Monday afternoon, as were many of the Web sites hosted on its serve...

headline: A New Kind of Warfare
abstract: Nations are developing disruptive offensive software — at great potential risk.
snippet: Nations are developing disruptive offensive software — at great potential risk.
lead_paragraph: Cybersecurity efforts in the United States have largely centered on defending computer networks against attacks by hackers, criminals and foreign governments, mainly China. Increasingly, however, the focus is on developing offensive capabilities, on figuring out how and when the United States might unleash its own malware to disrupt an adversary’s networks. That is potentially dangerous territory.

headline: Al Jazeera Wrests Back Its Web Sites From Pro-Assad Hackers
abstract: The news organization reported that the cyber attack lasted several hours, by affecting a third-party service provider that distributes the station’s online content worldwide in a security breach.
snippet: The news organization reported that the cyber attack lasted several hours, by affecting a third-party service provider that distributes the station’s online content worldwide in a security breach.

snippet: Hackers have released a file that they say contains more than one million identification numbers for Apple iPhones, iPads and iPod Touch devices. They claim to have obtained the file by hacking into the computer of a federal agent, though the F.B....

headline: Can This Company Recover From a Cyberattack?
abstract: MyBizHomepage, a provider of business accounting software, was shut down by a wave of cyber attacks that apparently came from a disgruntled former employee.
snippet: MyBizHomepage, a provider of business accounting software, was shut down by a wave of cyber attacks that apparently came from a disgruntled former employee.
lead_paragraph: A case study we’ve just published explains the challenges faced by Peter Justen, chief executive of MyBizHomepage, a Middleburg, Va., provider of business accounting software. The business was shut down by a wave of cyber attacks that apparently came from a disgruntled former employee.

headline: Struggling to Recover From a Cyberattack
abstract: When someone hacks into a company’s computer system and wreaks havoc, and a former employee is suspected, how does the business rebuild?
snippet: When someone hacks into a company’s computer system and wreaks havoc, and a former employee is suspected, how does the business rebuild?
lead_paragraph: IN 2006, Peter Justen, a serial entrepreneur, founded MyBizHomepage, an online service that connected to companies’ QuickBooks accounting software to help business owners monitor their financial metrics. When the site went live in 2008, it attracted significant media attention. It was free to use and the company planned to make money through advertising, a recipe that appealed to Mr. Justen’s investors, who valued the company at $100 million based on the vast potential they perceived.

headline: Virus Seeking Bank Data Is Tied to Attack on Iran
abstract: A security firm said it had discovered what it believed was the fourth state-sponsored computer virus to surface in the Middle East in the last three years, one apparently aimed at collecting information from computers in Lebanon. It appears to have been written by the same programmers who designed Flame, which was found to be spying on computers in Iran.

headline: Rebuking Critics of Leaks, Top Counterterrorism Adviser Seeks a Little Room

headline: Silicon Valley Sounds Off on Failed Cybersecurity Legislation
abstract: A cybersecurity bill that would have set security standards for the computer networks that govern the nation’s critical infrastructure was blocked by a Republican filibuster in the Senate on Thursday. We talked to three cybersecurity experts in Silicon Valley to get their take on the bill, opportunities missed and whether the threat of a 9/11-style cyberattack is imminent.

headline: Cybersecurity at Risk
abstract: If a catastrophic cyberattack occurs in the United States, Americans will be justified in asking why their lawmakers failed to protect them.
snippet: If a catastrophic cyberattack occurs in the United States, Americans will be justified in asking why their lawmakers failed to protect them.
lead_paragraph: Relentless assaults on America’s computer networks by China and other foreign governments, hackers and criminals have created an urgent need for safeguards to protect these vital systems. The question now is whether the Senate will provide them. Senator John McCain, a Republican of Arizona, and the Chamber of Commerce have already exacted compromises from sponsors of a reasonably strong bill, and are asking for more. Their demands should be resisted and the original bill approved by the Senate.

headline: Rise Is Seen in Cyberattacks Targeting U.S. Infrastructure
abstract: Gen. Keith B. Alexander of the National Security Agency said that the nation was not fully prepared for the attacks on electricity grids, water supplies and other targets.
snippet: Gen. Keith B. Alexander of the National Security Agency said that the nation was not fully prepared for the attacks on electricity grids, water supplies and other targets.
lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — The top American military official responsible for defending the United States against cyberattacks said Thursday that there had been a 17-fold increase in computer attacks on American infrastructure between 2009 and 2011, initiated by criminal gangs, hackers and other nations.

headline: Iranian Scientist Claims U.S. Cyberattack Was … Loud
abstract: A scientist with Iran’s atomic energy agency said the United States used “Thunderstruck” by AC/DC in an attack on the program’s computers.
snippet: A scientist with Iran’s atomic energy agency said the United States used “Thunderstruck” by AC/DC in an attack on the program’s computers.
lead_paragraph: The United States has a rather bizarre history of blasting rock music into the ears of presumed enemies, so it seemed plausible when a prominent security expert reported Monday that a new cyberattack on Iran’s atomic program included workstations erupting in booms of “Thunderstruck” by AC/DC, an Australian rock band.

headline: British Police Say Climate E-mail Case Was Crime, While Giving Up the Chase
abstract: A British police force concludes that the release of climate e-mails was a crime, and closes the unsolved case.
snippet: A British police force concludes that the release of climate e-mails was a crime, and closes the unsolved case.
lead_paragraph: Apologies for the delay on this post, but I was out on the Hudson yesterday with “River University” students seining for fish and probing mud samples when the Norfolk Constabulary, the local British police force investigating the 2009 disclosure of e-mails and files from the University of East Anglia climate unit, finally officially deemed the incident a crime — even as it closed the case, conceding that it was uncrackable.

headline: Apple Tweaks Its ‘We’re Safe’ Message and Antivirus Makers Take Notice
abstract: Apple, which once bragged that that its Mac computer “Doesn’t get PC viruses,” recently tweaked its marketing message to read: “Built to be safe.” Antivirus makers have been quick to call the tweak an official admission by Apple that this computers are no longer immune from attacks common to PCs running Windows. Or is it just the latest instance of antivirus makers over-hyping a threat to sell more product because Apple is selling significantly more computers than ever before?
snippet: Apple, which once bragged that that its Mac computer “Doesn’t get PC viruses,” recently tweaked its marketing message to read: “Built to be safe.” Antivirus makers have been quick to call the tweak an official admission by Apple that this computer...
lead_paragraph: It was a subtle tweak, but it didn’t go unnoticed by antivirus software makers for long.

headline: A Weapon We Can’t Control
abstract: The United States should pursue an international treaty regulating cyberweapons — or face the consequences.
snippet: The United States should pursue an international treaty regulating cyberweapons — or face the consequences.

headline: It’s as Easy as 123!@S
abstract: As our dependency on the Internet has grown, so has the complexity of its restrictions. The end result: a mind-boggling array of personal codes.
snippet: As our dependency on the Internet has grown, so has the complexity of its restrictions. The end result: a mind-boggling array of personal codes.
lead_paragraph: WITH numbers. Without. One capital letter. None. More than eight characters. Fewer than 16.

headline: Asleep at the Laptop
abstract: With all the attention to the so-called fiscal cliff, it is equally important to ask whether collective inaction has us barreling toward a cybercliff.
snippet: With all the attention to the so-called fiscal cliff, it is equally important to ask whether collective inaction has us barreling toward a cybercliff.
lead_paragraph: THE alarm bells sound regularly: cybergeddon; the next Pearl Harbor; one of the greatest existential threats facing the United States. With increasing frequency, these are the grave terms officials invoke about the menace of cybercrime — and they’re not understating the threat.

headline: Obama’s Counterterrorism Actions Complicate Republican Strategy
abstract: A report in The New York Times is the latest evidence that Mr. Obama has embraced the use of his predecessor’s national security and anti-terrorism machinery.
snippet: A report in The New York Times is the latest evidence that Mr. Obama has embraced the use of his predecessor’s national security and anti-terrorism machinery.
lead_paragraph: The revelation that President Obama has been personally and secretly directing a covert cyberwar against Iran could have political implications as the president enters the final stretch of his re-election campaign against Mitt Romney this year.

headline: Small Cameras That Can Switch Focus or Ride a Bike
abstract: As more and more people take pictures using their cellphone, manufacturers are producing interesting and unusual cameras that can still fit in pocket.
snippet: As more and more people take pictures using their cellphone, manufacturers are producing interesting and unusual cameras that can still fit in pocket.
lead_paragraph: POINT-AND-SHOOT cameras are being assaulted on all fronts. Smartphones are threatening to make pocket-size cameras unnecessary by offering passable results on a device many people are already carrying around. Meanwhile, photographers who want better performance are likely to be tempted by mirrorless interchangeable lens cameras, which are shrinking to nearly pocket size while offering features like those found on professional-level, single-lens reflex cameras.

headline: Malicious E-Mail Attachment on Olympics Making Rounds on the Internet
abstract: A schedule of the 2012 London Olympics has been circulating on the Internet that, alas, is not a schedule, but a Chinese cyber attack. The advice: Don’t open it.
snippet: A schedule of the 2012 London Olympics has been circulating on the Internet that, alas, is not a schedule, but a Chinese cyber attack. The advice: Don’t open it.
lead_paragraph: Olympics enthusiasts: You may want to think twice before opening that PDF e-mail attachment of the 2012 Olympics schedule.

headline: Iran Confirms Attack by Virus That Collects Information
abstract: Though newly identified, the virus, called Flame, could be five years old, experts say. It is designed not to do damage, but to collect information from sources.
snippet: Though newly identified, the virus, called Flame, could be five years old, experts say. It is designed not to do damage, but to collect information from sources.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The computers of high-ranking Iranian officials appear to have been penetrated by a data-mining virus called Flame, in what may be the most destructive cyberattack on Iran since the notorious Stuxnet virus, an Iranian cyberdefense organization confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Israel Gets the Blame for Flame Virus
abstract: A new powerful weapon in the cyber war has been unleashed, according to Russian researchers. Iran seems to be the main target of the Flame virus, so is Israel responsible?
snippet: A new powerful weapon in the cyber war has been unleashed, according to Russian researchers. Iran seems to be the main target of the Flame virus, so is Israel responsible?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — No prize for guessing who is getting the blame – or should that be the credit – for creating a new spyware super bug reported to have infected computers throughout the Middle East.

headline: New Under the Sun: Books for Basking
abstract: Here’s a sampling of beach reads to suit every taste, from history to science fiction.
snippet: Here’s a sampling of beach reads to suit every taste, from history to science fiction.
lead_paragraph: The heroine of this year’s best beach read was beheaded 476 years ago. The most chilling nonfiction spy story unfolds in cyberspace. The coolest biographical subject is a comic-book character. The hottest history is recent. The most amazing act of kindness is performed by an elephant. The most Harry Potter-ish action-adventure romance unfolds against the backdrop of the Arab Spring. And the Olympian Walter Cronkite shares space on the TV shelf with the guy behind Bravo’s “Real Housewives” shows.

headline: Hackers Breach Sites of Foreign Policy and Human Rights Groups
abstract: Security researchers have discovered that hackers breached Web sites belonging to several foreign policy and human rights groups using security flaws in Adobe and Oracle software. Among the sites still infected were sites belonging to Amnesty International Hong Kong, the Center for Defense Information and the Cambodian Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
snippet: Security researchers have discovered that hackers breached Web sites belonging to several foreign policy and human rights groups using security flaws in Adobe and Oracle software. Among the sites still infected were sites belonging to Amnesty Inte...
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, hackers have breached Web sites belonging to several foreign policy and human rights groups, including Amnesty International and the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism, a nonprofit organization based in Israel that researches terrorism issues.

headline: Malware for Macs Lucrative, Security Researchers Say
abstract: Long told that they were safe from computer viruses and malware attacks, Apple users last month fell victim to the largest-scale malware attack on Macs to date. Security experts now estimate that the malware made cyber criminals $10,000 a day.
snippet: Long told that they were safe from computer viruses and malware attacks, Apple users last month fell victim to the largest-scale malware attack on Macs to date. Security experts now estimate that the malware made cyber criminals $10,000 a day.
lead_paragraph: Last month, cybercriminals embarked on what quickly became one of the largest-scale malware attacks on Apple computers to date. Their motive was financial: security researchers now estimate that the infected computers made the malware’s creators $10,000 a day.

headline: House Votes to Approve Disputed Hacking Bill
abstract: The vote defies a promised presidential veto on a bill that encourages intelligence agencies and businesses to share information on cyberthreats.
snippet: The vote defies a promised presidential veto on a bill that encourages intelligence agencies and businesses to share information on cyberthreats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defying a veto threat from President Obama, the House on Thursday passed a bill that encourages intelligence agencies and businesses to share information about threats to computer systems, including attacks on American Web sites by hackers in China and other countries.

headline: Nissan Is Latest Company to Get Hacked
abstract: Nissan said it was hacked two weeks ago. The intruders stole employees’ log-in credentials, but the company said its intellectual property and consumer data had not been breached. The incident is just the latest in a string of cyberattacks on companies, in which the culprit is difficult to trace.
snippet: Nissan said it was hacked two weeks ago. The intruders stole employees’ log-in credentials, but the company said its intellectual property and consumer data had not been breached. The incident is just the latest in a string of cyberattacks on comp...
lead_paragraph: Nissan confirmed its computer systems were hacked two weeks ago.

snippet: Asheem Chandna, a partner at Greylock Partners, is a board member at Imperva and Palo Alto Networks and an investor in more than a dozen security-focused start-ups. He talks about how the nature of the cybersecurity threat is changing and what opp...
lead_paragraph: Every week now, we get a jolting reminder of just how vulnerable our personal, financial and national security information is to hackers — and how inadequate existing security solutions have become.

snippet: Foreign hackers are stealing America’s corporate secrets, and Congress is doing nothing to stop them.

headline: Chinese Grad Student Hacks Indian Military Research Firms
abstract: More than 200 security breaches reported, all traced to one former graduate student.
snippet: More than 200 security breaches reported, all traced to one former graduate student.
lead_paragraph: India’s military preparedness and the possibility of defense breaches has dominated the news after Army chief V.K.. Singh’s letter to Prime Minister Manmohan Singh surfaced recently calling India’s weapons “obsolete.”

headline: Europe Cracks Down on Cybercrime
abstract: Internet crime costs billions of euros a year, but a lack of coordination between countries has hampered efforts to detect and prosecute offenders. The Union moved this week to change that.
snippet: Internet crime costs billions of euros a year, but a lack of coordination between countries has hampered efforts to detect and prosecute offenders. The Union moved this week to change that.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Union is preparing new steps to crack down on bot-herders, identity thieves, web hijackers and other online fraudsters who are skimming millions of euros a day from a growing number of its half billion citizens.

headline: Crime, Punishment and the Rutgers Case
abstract: Readers react to the conviction of Dharun Ravi in the Rutgers hate crime case.
snippet: Readers react to the conviction of Dharun Ravi in the Rutgers hate crime case.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: While You Were Gone
abstract: A psychic heroine searches for answers about her dead mother.
snippet: A psychic heroine searches for answers about her dead mother.
lead_paragraph: The darkly comic world of Heidi Julavits’s latest novel contains warring psychics, missing people who’ve deliberately vanished themselves, twisted avant-garde filmmakers, absent mothers, striving academics, plastic surgery enthusiasts, Sylvia Plath obsessives — and the people who love to hate and pursue all of them. Beneath this hyperactivity, the novel deals, fundamentally, with the “economics of revenge” and a daughter’s search for her mother. It is told in Julavits’s signature style: sharp-eyed, sardonic, hilarious.

headline: New Interest in Hacking as Threat to Security
abstract: An increase in attacks on computer systems that control critical infrastructure, factories and databases has prompted a new focus on cybersecurity legislation.
snippet: An increase in attacks on computer systems that control critical infrastructure, factories and databases has prompted a new focus on cybersecurity legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the five-month period between October and February, there were 86 reported attacks on computer systems in the United States that control critical infrastructure, factories and databases, according to the Department of Homeland Security, compared with 11 over the same period a year ago.

headline: Europe Must Defend Itself
abstract: Guest commentator Brigitte Adès writes that with the U.S. cutting nearly a half-trillion dollars in defense spending over ten years, Europe and NATO must evolve. The question is, are they ready?
snippet: Guest commentator Brigitte Adès writes that with the U.S. cutting nearly a half-trillion dollars in defense spending over ten years, Europe and NATO must evolve. The question is, are they ready?
lead_paragraph: After President Barack Obama’s announcement this year of significant changes to the U.S. defense strategy, the world has mostly focused on the shift toward Asia and the Pacific. However. this is only one aspect of the new U.S. posture. It also has a great impact from a European defense point of view, as senior American strategists and NATO officials told me during the meeting of NATO defense ministers in Brussels last month.

headline: Tap Into the Gifted Young Hackers
abstract: We need to learn about hackers, engage with them more and examine if and how we can use their skills as a force for good.
snippet: We need to learn about hackers, engage with them more and examine if and how we can use their skills as a force for good.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers are not usually the main targets of the F.B.I., whose agents are used to dealing with hardened criminals. But for the Cyber Division, they appear to be the norm.

headline: London Calling
abstract: This weekend’s magazine was devoted to London. While it’s a “photography issue,” it does include writers and text, of course. But — also of course — there’s no way we could have included enough words or pictures to justly capture the city’s literary lion-icity. Here’s an arbitrary, unrepresentative sampling from some of the writers who go on and on about the place.
snippet: This weekend’s magazine was devoted to London. While it’s a “photography issue,” it does include writers and text, of course. But — also of course — there’s no way we could have included enough words or pictures to justly capture the city’s litera...
lead_paragraph: Last fall, National Geographic Traveler ranked London No. 3 on its list of the world’s “Top 10 Literary Cities.” It’s a mystery it didn’t finish first: what other burg belongs in the running for the all-time City of Writers title? (Nos. 1 and 2 were also in the British Isles, for what that’s worth.) As a Stanford University site called Authorial London puts it, “A comprehensive Web site for literary London would occupy an entire server.” See for yourself — check out the pantheon hosted there. And note that it’s pretty much just an old-timer’s wing.

headline: Interpol Site Knocked Offline Following Anonymous Arrests
abstract: Interpol’s Web site went down Tuesday just hours after the international police agency announced the arrest of 25 suspected members of the hacking collective Anonymous in Argentina, Chile, Colombia and Spain.
snippet: Interpol’s Web site went down Tuesday just hours after the international police agency announced the arrest of 25 suspected members of the hacking collective Anonymous in Argentina, Chile, Colombia and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Interpol’s Web site went down Tuesday just hours after the international police agency announced the arrest of 25 suspected members of the hacking collective Anonymous in Argentina, Chile, Colombia and Spain.

headline: Campaigning Against the Modern World
abstract: Rick Santorum isn’t happy with the first Catholic president either.
snippet: Rick Santorum isn’t happy with the first Catholic president either.
lead_paragraph: As a journalist who covered Rick Santorum in Pennsylvania for years, I can understand the Tea Party’s infatuation with him. It’s his anger. It is in perfect synch with the constituency he is wooing.

headline: Preparing for DDoS Attacks or Just Groundhog Day
abstract: A number of companies help Web sites fight basic cyber attacks and unexpected traffic, but most are prohibitively expensive. CloudFlare, a two-year-old San Francisco start-up, helps defend Web sites from cyber attacks on the cheap. Two years in, it counts Groundhog.org, Metallica and Stratfor as customers.
snippet: A number of companies help Web sites fight basic cyber attacks and unexpected traffic, but most are prohibitively expensive. CloudFlare, a two-year-old San Francisco start-up, helps defend Web sites from cyber attacks on the cheap. Two years in, i...
lead_paragraph: A “distributed denial of service” attack — or what security gurus call a DDoS attack — is a little like what happens to Groundhog.org on Groundhog Day.

headline: Hacking Group Attacks Weapons Maker
abstract: Hackers observing the one-year anniversary of the uprising in Bahrain attacked Combined Systems, a company based in Jamestown, Pa., saying that the attack was in retaliation for the company’s sale of chemical weapons “to repress our revolutionary movements.”
snippet: Hackers observing the one-year anniversary of the uprising in Bahrain attacked Combined Systems, a company based in Jamestown, Pa., saying that the attack was in retaliation for the company’s sale of chemical weapons “to repress our revolutionary ...
lead_paragraph: While many celebrated Valentine’s Day on Tuesday, hackers celebrated a different holiday: the one-year anniversary of the uprising in Bahrain, sometimes called the February 14 Revolution. They attacked Combined Systems, a company based in Jamestown, Pa., saying that the attack was in retaliation for sales by the company of chemical weapons “to repress our revolutionary movements.”

headline: Anonymous Says It Knocked C.I.A. Site Offline
abstract: Hackers claimed responsibility for knocking the Web site of the Central Intelligence Agency offline, under the banner of the hacking collective Anonymous. By late Friday afternoon, the site was still unavailable.
snippet: Hackers claimed responsibility for knocking the Web site of the Central Intelligence Agency offline, under the banner of the hacking collective Anonymous. By late Friday afternoon, the site was still unavailable.
lead_paragraph: Hackers claimed responsibility for knocking the Web site of the Central Intelligence Agency offline on Friday, under the banner of the hacking collective Anonymous. By late Friday afternoon, the site was still unavailable.

headline: Santorum Rose Quickly From Reformer to Insider
abstract: When Rick Santorum entered the House in 1991, he joined with a group of other freshmen to shame the House leadership into releasing the names of those who bounced checks at the House bank.
snippet: When Rick Santorum entered the House in 1991, he joined with a group of other freshmen to shame the House leadership into releasing the names of those who bounced checks at the House bank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rick Santorum arrived on Capitol Hill as a new member of Congress in January 1991, 32 years old and bristling with the impatience of a man looking to kick up a fuss. Eight months later, he got his chance when he learned of lawmaker overdrafts at the little-known House bank.

headline: Even Big Companies Cannot Protect Their Data
abstract: Breaches that hit two Amazon-owned sites, Zappos.com and 6PM, over the weekend point to an unsettling truth: even the biggest players on the Web cannot guarantee that their customers’ personal information is safe. Instead, many security experts throw the burden back to consumers by recommending that consumers take a more vigilant approach to protecting their personal data

This is why, each year, the World Economic Forum poses the question, “What risks should the world’s leaders be addressing over the next 10 years?”

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The credit card details of more than 20,000 Israelis were exposed on the Internet in two waves this week by a hacker or team of hackers who said they were Saudis.

headline: Insurance Against Cyber Attacks Expected to Boom
abstract: Despite high-profile cyber attacks at Sony, Google, Epsilon, RSA and others this year, only a third of companies surveyed by Advisen, a research group, say they have purchased a cyber insurance policy. Experts say that more companies will get policies in the coming year because of Security and Exchange Commission rules requiring companies to disclose cyber attacks and their costs to shareholders.

snippet: An Iranian newspaper reported plans for an “exhibition” of seven captured drones as an American military report warned of vulnerabilities in their communication systems.
lead_paragraph: After flaunting its capture of a sophisticated American spy drone on national television last week, Iran is said to be planning to invite local reporters and foreign diplomats to an even more spectacular display of pilotless hardware in the near future.

headline: Another ‘Special’ Day, Another Retail Dollar
abstract: The Day: Snappy sales gimmicks attached to specific days of the week may be the country’s best hope for climbing out of its economic doldrums. Also, what City Room is reading in other newspapers and blogs.
snippet: The Day: Snappy sales gimmicks attached to specific days of the week may be the country’s best hope for climbing out of its economic doldrums. Also, what City Room is reading in other newspapers and blogs.
lead_paragraph: It has become increasingly clear that the country’s best hope to climb out of its economic doldrums may be to keep coming up with snappy sales gimmicks attached to specific days of the week. That’s what now passes for a recovery plan. New York, with its many retailers, hardly stands apart from the trend.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 25

snippet: Journalists report being assaulted covering protests in Egypt, Black Friday becomes a media event and J.K. Rowling testifies about British press practices.
lead_paragraph: The Egyptian-American journalist Mona Eltahawy took to Twitter on Thursday to say that she had been sexually assaulted by security forces after being arrested at the protests in Cairo’s Tahrir Square. Her Tweeted reporting on the attacks she suffered during her 12 hours inside the Interior Ministry building has been collected at The Guardian. Her account includes a photo of her arms in a cast, after X-rays showed they had been broken, and her recollection, “The whole time I was thinking about article I would write.” [The Guardian]

headline: Decline and Fall
abstract: Gloom has settled on the world. Even the French are no longer sure their culture is superior.
snippet: Gloom has settled on the world. Even the French are no longer sure their culture is superior.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Everyone’s so glum and gloomy. I suppose this is what decline looks like: the faces in the laundromat. It puts me in mind of Rome circa 475 A.D., Visigoths on the prowl.

headline: 7 Charged in Web Scam Using Ads
abstract: Federal prosecutors charged seven men with orchestrating an Internet scheme that infected more than four million computers with malicious software and generated profits through online advertisements.
snippet: Federal prosecutors charged seven men with orchestrating an Internet scheme that infected more than four million computers with malicious software and generated profits through online advertisements.
lead_paragraph: It was a subtle swap: a cheesy advertisement for a vacation timeshare site atop the home page of ESPN.com, in a spot that might have been claimed by a well-known brand like Dr Pepper.

headline: America’s Deadly Dynamics With Iran
abstract: Many believe America’s shadow war with Iran is about to ramp up dramatically.
snippet: Many believe America’s shadow war with Iran is about to ramp up dramatically.
lead_paragraph: COMMUTING to work in Tehran is never easy, but it is particularly nerve-racking these days for the scientists of Shahid Beheshti University. It was a little less than a year ago when one of them, Majid Shahriari, and his wife were stuck in traffic at 7:40 a.m. and a motorcycle pulled up alongside the car. There was a faint “click” as a magnet attached to the driver’s side door. The huge explosion came a few seconds later, killing him and injuring his wife.

headline: U.S. Weighs Its Strategy on Warfare in Cyberspace
abstract: Officials are working to clarify a military doctrine on waging cyberattacks after a plan for such an attack on Libya was rejected.
snippet: Officials are working to clarify a military doctrine on waging cyberattacks after a plan for such an attack on Libya was rejected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The four-star Air Force general who oversees Pentagon efforts in cyberspace acknowledged Tuesday that the Defense Department had more work to do in clarifying the military’s doctrine for waging offensive computer warfare and setting up rules of engagement to guide specific cyberattacks.

headline: Protests Are a Payday for Security Firms
abstract: For the high-end security firms that protect the moneyed elite, Occupy Wall Street has been a stimulus package all its own.
snippet: For the high-end security firms that protect the moneyed elite, Occupy Wall Street has been a stimulus package all its own.
lead_paragraph: They call when they make the Forbes 400 list. They call when annual hedge fund rankings appear, when their names are mentioned on CNBC and when their children travel abroad. And, these days, they call when protesters camped in Lower Manhattan grow uncomfortable with the idea of their existence.

headline: U.S. Debated Cyberwarfare in Attack Plan on Libya
abstract: Obama administration officials decided to use airstrikes to disrupt and disable the Qaddafi government in March, but only after a new kind of warfare was discussed.
snippet: Obama administration officials decided to use airstrikes to disrupt and disable the Qaddafi government in March, but only after a new kind of warfare was discussed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just before the American-led strikes against Libya in March, the Obama administration intensely debated whether to open the mission with a new kind of warfare: a cyberoffensive to disrupt and even disable the Qaddafi government’s air-defense system, which threatened allied warplanes.

headline: Mexico Turns to Social Media for Information and Survival
abstract: Social media has become a necessity in Mexico, with a mission far different from that of the Arab revolutions — here, it is deployed for local survival.
snippet: Social media has become a necessity in Mexico, with a mission far different from that of the Arab revolutions — here, it is deployed for local survival.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Before the police or news reporters had even arrived at the underpass outside Veracruz where gunmen held up traffic and dumped 35 bodies at rush hour last week, Twitter was already buzzing with fear and valuable information.

headline: Visions of an Age When Oil Isn’t King
abstract: In “The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World,” Daniel Yergin returns to the topic of how energy policy is driving global change.
snippet: In “The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World,” Daniel Yergin returns to the topic of how energy policy is driving global change.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Yergin is America’s most influential energy pundit, and the book that put him on the map was “The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power” (1991). It was a best seller, won a Pulitzer Prize and was tailored into a popular PBS mini-series. In the two decades since, Mr. Yergin, operating as a kind of one-man think tank, has had a virtual monopoly on the subject of energy and geopolitics. Such is his influence that one half expects his competitors to file antitrust litigation against him.

headline: Executives May Be Too Confident on Cybersecurity, Survey Finds
abstract: Global executives are confident in their ability to secure their information systems, but few are actually on top of their companies’ security issues, a PricewaterhouseCoopers survey found.
snippet: Global executives are confident in their ability to secure their information systems, but few are actually on top of their companies’ security issues, a PricewaterhouseCoopers survey found.
lead_paragraph: Every week comes a new report warning how vulnerable consumers, companies and government agencies are to hackers bent on breaching computer systems and extracting sensitive data.

headline: Colorful, Digital, Virtual
abstract: So far, the spring/summer 2012 season in New York can be summed up in surreal flower prints, geometric patterns and a vibrant exploration of fabric and style.
snippet: So far, the spring/summer 2012 season in New York can be summed up in surreal flower prints, geometric patterns and a vibrant exploration of fabric and style.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The minute’s silence on Sunday morning honored the victims on the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attack, and gave food for thought. So much has changed in the past decade, in fashion as in the rest of the world.

headline: Android Is No. 1 Target of Mobile Hackers

snippet: A report from McAfee said that Android is now the most targeted mobile software by hackers and malware developers.

headline: After 9/11, an Era of Tinker, Tailor, Jihadist, Spy
abstract: It took years after 9/11 for policy makers to realize they could draw on cold-war-style thinking and skulduggery to protect America from its new global enemies.
snippet: It took years after 9/11 for policy makers to realize they could draw on cold-war-style thinking and skulduggery to protect America from its new global enemies.
lead_paragraph: Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker are reporters for The New York Times and authors of the forthcoming “Counterstrike: The Untold Story of America’s Secret Campaign Against Al Qaeda,” from which this article is adapted.

snippet: A remote-controlled plane that can snoop quietly on wireless networks and attack them was on display at the Black Hat conference in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: It flies. It spies. It is the color of sunshine, and it has googly eyes.

headline: Security Firm Sees Global Cyberspying
abstract: Targets of attacks identified by McAfee included a wide range of governments and American corporations.
snippet: Targets of attacks identified by McAfee included a wide range of governments and American corporations.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — An American cybersecurity company issued a report on Wednesday saying that it had identified a single perpetrator of cyberattacks that lasted up to five years on a wide range of governments, American corporations and even United Nations groups, and that the pattern of targets suggested the attacker was a “state actor.”

snippet: Federal authorities in Washington are expected to announce charges on Tuesday against about a dozen suspected members of the hacker group Anonymous, officials said.
lead_paragraph: 6:15 p.m. | Updated Adding news of arrests by authorities.

headline: Hackers Gained Access to Sensitive Military Files
abstract: As the Pentagon announced a new cyberspace strategy, it disclosed a serious digital attack in March.
snippet: As the Pentagon announced a new cyberspace strategy, it disclosed a serious digital attack in March.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department suffered one of its worst digital attacks in history in March, when a foreign intelligence service hacked into the computer system of a corporate contractor and obtained 24,000 Pentagon files during a single intrusion, senior officials said Thursday.

headline: Hackers Release More Data From Arizona Police
abstract: Hackers publicly exposed for the second time information they claimed to have stolen from the computer systems and personnel of the Arizona state police.
snippet: Hackers publicly exposed for the second time information they claimed to have stolen from the computer systems and personnel of the Arizona state police.
lead_paragraph: Hackers on Wednesday publicly exposed for the second time information they claimed to have stolen from the computer systems and personnel of the Arizona state police, in a continuation of a nearly two-month hacking spree.

abstract: With a global hacking attack and the rise of apps cutting into PlayStation’s power, Sony shuffles the top management for its video game unit.
snippet: With a global hacking attack and the rise of apps cutting into PlayStation’s power, Sony shuffles the top management for its video game unit.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Sony said on Wednesday that it would shuffle the management of its video game unit, two months after an extensive hacking attack forced the company to shut down its popular PlayStation Network.

headline: Hackers Declare War on Government Agencies
abstract: Lulz Security, a hacker group, said over the weekend that it was initiating cyber warfare with governments and security companies around the world.
snippet: Lulz Security, a hacker group, said over the weekend that it was initiating cyber warfare with governments and security companies around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Internet may be about to get a little more chaotic than usual. Over the weekend, a group of hackers declared that they are initiating cyber warfare with governments and security companies around the world.

headline: Thieves Found Citigroup Site an Easy Entry
abstract: Using the Citigroup customer Web site as a gateway to bypass traditional safeguards and impersonate actual credit card holders, thieves cracked into the bank’s reservoir of personal data.
snippet: Using the Citigroup customer Web site as a gateway to bypass traditional safeguards and impersonate actual credit card holders, thieves cracked into the bank’s reservoir of personal data.
lead_paragraph: Think of it as a mansion with a high-tech security system — but the front door wasn’t locked tight.

headline: Hackers Claim to Breach Senate’s Web Site
abstract: Lulz Security, a group of hackers responsible for a wave of attacks online, claimed Monday to have breached Bethesda Software, a video game company, and the Web site of the United States Senate.
snippet: Lulz Security, a group of hackers responsible for a wave of attacks online, claimed Monday to have breached Bethesda Software, a video game company, and the Web site of the United States Senate.

headline: In India, Dynamism Wrestles With Dysfunction
abstract: In Gurgaon and elsewhere in India, economic growth is often the product of a private sector’s improvising to overcome government inadequacies.
snippet: In Gurgaon and elsewhere in India, economic growth is often the product of a private sector’s improvising to overcome government inadequacies.
lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — In this city that barely existed two decades ago, there are 26 shopping malls, seven golf courses and luxury shops selling Chanel and Louis Vuitton. Mercedes-Benzes and BMWs shimmer in automobile showrooms. Apartment towers are sprouting like concrete weeds, and a futuristic commercial hub called Cyber City houses many of the world’s most respected corporations.

headline: Pentagon to Consider Cyberattacks Acts of War
abstract: The Pentagon plans to declare that a computer attack from a foreign nation can be considered an act of war.
snippet: The Pentagon plans to declare that a computer attack from a foreign nation can be considered an act of war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon, trying to create a formal strategy to deter cyberattacks on the United States, plans to issue a new strategy soon declaring that a computer attack from a foreign nation can be considered an act of war that may result in a military response.

headline: Words You Don’t Say
abstract: The Times magazine staff enjoyed readers’ response to our post about Kurt Andersen’s “Words We Don’t Say” so much that we posted an unabridged list of your suggestions on our office wall. It is, however, not all that practical. If we ceased to use all the words that readers don’t want us to use, we might publish a blank magazine.
snippet: The Times magazine staff enjoyed readers’ response to our post about Kurt Andersen’s “Words We Don’t Say” so much that we posted an unabridged list of your suggestions on our office wall. It is, however, not all that practical. If we ceased to use...
lead_paragraph: The Times magazine staff enjoyed readers’ response to our post about Kurt Andersen’s “Words We Don’t Say” so much that we posted an unabridged list of your suggestions on our office wall. It is, however, not all that practical. If we ceased to use all the words that readers don’t want us to use, we might publish a blank magazine. Some of your explanations were erudite. Others were downright funny. We know one thing: We will never use impact as a verb ever again.

headline: Switzerland Decides on Nuclear Phase-Out
abstract: The decision not to build new reactors came as regulators from the European Union agreed on a framework for stress-testing their plants.
snippet: The decision not to build new reactors came as regulators from the European Union agreed on a framework for stress-testing their plants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The Swiss government decided Wednesday to abandon plans to build new nuclear reactors, while European Union regulators agreed on a framework for stress-testing theirs, as repercussions from the disaster in Japan continue to ripple across Europe.

headline: Who Could Become the Data Sheriff?
abstract: A number of lawmakers have promised that new federal online privacy legislation is on the way, but privacy experts believe politics and a lack of understanding in government will curb new laws.
snippet: A number of lawmakers have promised that new federal online privacy legislation is on the way, but privacy experts believe politics and a lack of understanding in government will curb new laws.
lead_paragraph: In an article I wrote for the Week in Review section last Sunday, I noted that no federal laws existed to punish companies when customers’ personal information and data were stolen in cyber-attacks, or mishandled by companies. And so punishment in these cases is left up to the states. Yet in many instances, state officials don’t have the resources to tackle this problem, and even acknowledge that they don’t always understand the technical aspects of breaches.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Profiting From Osama, Dealing With the Dollar
abstract: Plus, how do you tackle big problems?
snippet: Plus, how do you tackle big problems?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Making the Holocaust the Lesson on All Evils
abstract: The Museum of Tolerance is symptomatic of how the Holocaust is generalized to tie together all kinds of evils.
snippet: The Museum of Tolerance is symptomatic of how the Holocaust is generalized to tie together all kinds of evils.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before you are submerged within the museum’s theatrically darkened central galleries, before you learn how the cafes and intellectual life of the Weimar Republic gradually gave way to the annihilationist racial fantasies Hitler outlined in “Mein Kampf” — before, that is, you experience a variation of the Holocaust narrative with its wrenching genocidal climax — there are other trials a visitor to the Museum of Tolerance here must pass through.

headline: On Pinwheels, Networks and Resilience
abstract: Sustaining flows of information on the path to durable human progress.
snippet: Sustaining flows of information on the path to durable human progress.
lead_paragraph: I had an utterly minor experience today that helped reinforce my personal sense of where to focus if the goal is fostering a relatively smooth ride as human populations and appetites crest in coming decades.

headline: The Asymmetrical Online War
abstract: Hardly a week passes when there isn’t some new incident underscoring the fundamental imbalance of power in cyberspace between attacker and defender.
snippet: Hardly a week passes when there isn’t some new incident underscoring the fundamental imbalance of power in cyberspace between attacker and defender.
lead_paragraph: In 1975, John Brunner wrote a science fiction novel, “The Shockwave Rider,” about a lone programmer who creates a computer worm that exposes a repressive regime’s secrets and ultimately undermines a tyrannical government.

headline: Nuances Attached
abstract: The proper way to ask someone to remove your children’s photos from their Facebook pages.
snippet: The proper way to ask someone to remove your children’s photos from their Facebook pages.
lead_paragraph: I sent the following message, via Facebook, to three family members: “I would like you to delete the photos of me and my young kids from your Facebook pages. I know you guys will understand. Thanks.” In reply, I received a text message and voice mail, telling me that my message was cold and rude. But I wanted to be short and to the point. Could I have done a better job?

headline: Radical Cleric Still Speaks on YouTube
abstract: The videos of Anwar al-Awlaki, the man some have called the Osama bin Laden of the Internet, still appear despite an effort by YouTube to remove them.
snippet: The videos of Anwar al-Awlaki, the man some have called the Osama bin Laden of the Internet, still appear despite an effort by YouTube to remove them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  From the shootings at Fort Hood, Tex., to the stabbing of a British member of Parliament, investigators have identified Anwar al-Awlaki’s stirring online calls to jihad as an important instigator of terrorism.

snippet: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: NATO Builds Its Cyberdefenses
abstract: Cyberspace is international by nature. No one country can deal effectively with cyberthreats on its own.
snippet: Cyberspace is international by nature. No one country can deal effectively with cyberthreats on its own.
lead_paragraph: Last November’s NATO summit in Lisbon agreed to a new security concept that frames the way the alliance will address the full range of emerging threats to our collective peace and security.

headline: Cyberspace Wars
abstract: The Internet has created a new dimension in national security: cyberterrorism, cyberespionage and cyberwar.
snippet: The Internet has created a new dimension in national security: cyberterrorism, cyberespionage and cyberwar.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, MASSACHUSETTS — This year, the 47th Munich Security Conference included for the first time a special session on cybersecurity. “This may be the first time,” the president of a small European noted to the high-powered assembly, more accustomed to dealing with armies and alliances than with worms and denial-of-service attacks, “but it will not be the last.”

headline: Attack on BMW Seller Shows Hazards of E-Commerce, Police Say
abstract: What the police say was Barion Blake’s wounding of Akeem Ajimotokan and theft of the $46,000 car he was selling demonstrates dangers of online transactions.
snippet: What the police say was Barion Blake’s wounding of Akeem Ajimotokan and theft of the $46,000 car he was selling demonstrates dangers of online transactions.
lead_paragraph: Since its beginnings, the Internet has been praised as an easy way to bring buyers and sellers together, for inexpensive household trinkets, high-end diamonds or even $46,000 sports cars. But with this convenience have come dangers  as demonstrated when Akeem Ajimotokan was found Wednesday, stabbed and stuffed in the trunk of his BMW M3 coupe.

headline: From Bullets to Megabytes
abstract: The cyber attack on Iran heralds a new global arms race.
snippet: The cyber attack on Iran heralds a new global arms race.
lead_paragraph: STUXNET, the computer worm that last year disrupted many of the gas centrifuges central to Iran’s nuclear program, is a powerful weapon in the new age of global information warfare. A sophisticated half-megabyte of computer code apparently accomplished what a half-decade of United Nations Security Council resolutions could not.

headline: Apocalypse in Cyberspace? It’s Overdone
abstract: Is a cyberwar already under way and, if so, could it really cause destruction on a large scale, as a number of recent books have asserted? Nonsense, says a new study.
snippet: Is a cyberwar already under way and, if so, could it really cause destruction on a large scale, as a number of recent books have asserted? Nonsense, says a new study.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Web site Cyberwarzone.com lists 270 books about Internet crime and warfare. In one of the highest-profile examples, “Cyber War: The Next Threat to National Security and What to Do About It,” Richard A. Clarke, the former U.S. counterterrorism chief, and Robert K. Knake of the Council on Foreign Relations, describe a digital “Day After” in which large parts of the U.S. transportation, energy and communications systems have been wiped out by Internet-borne attackers, leaving the authorities struggling to maintain control and consumers scrambling for food.

headline: A Leaner and Meaner Defense
abstract: America's massive defense costs are on the table, and there's lots that can be cut.
snippet: America's massive defense costs are on the table, and there's lots that can be cut.
lead_paragraph: Of all of this year’s seismic shifts in the deficit and debt debate, putting U.S. defense budgets on the table is perhaps the most significant.

headline: Cyberteeth Bared
abstract: Washington has worried that terrorists will become hackers. Perhaps we all should worry that hackers will become terrorists.
snippet: Washington has worried that terrorists will become hackers. Perhaps we all should worry that hackers will become terrorists.
lead_paragraph: 2010 was the year that removed all doubt that cybersecurity is now a geopolitical problem.
