headline: Updates on the WikiLeaks Saga, Day 12
abstract: On Thursday, the fallout from the publication of U.S. diplomatic cables obtained and distributed by WikiLeaks continues, one day after attacks by the group’s defenders took down the Web sites of Visa and MasterCard.
snippet: On Thursday, the fallout from the publication of U.S. diplomatic cables obtained and distributed by WikiLeaks continues, one day after attacks by the group’s defenders took down the Web sites of Visa and MasterCard.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the fallout from the publication of secret American diplomatic cables obtained and distributed by the WikiLeaks Web site continues, one day after cyber attacks by the group’s defenders took down the Web sites of first MasterCard and then Visa.

headline: ‘Operation Payback’ Attacks Fell Visa.com
abstract: A group of Internet activists took credit for crashing the Visa.com Web site on Wednesday afternoon, hours after they launched attacks on MasterCard.
snippet: A group of Internet activists took credit for crashing the Visa.com Web site on Wednesday afternoon, hours after they launched attacks on MasterCard.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated | 6:54 p.m. A group of Internet activists took credit for crashing the Visa.com Web site on Wednesday afternoon, hours after they launched a similar attack on MasterCard. The cyber attacks, by activists who call themselves Anonymous, are aimed at punishing companies that have acted to stop the flow of donations to WikiLeaks in recent days.

headline: State Dept. Daily Is Window on a Jittery Planet
abstract: For a select, high-security audience in a suspicious world, The Diplomatic Security Daily can’t be beat for its coverage of rumors and threats.
snippet: For a select, high-security audience in a suspicious world, The Diplomatic Security Daily can’t be beat for its coverage of rumors and threats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In Tunisia, a man was spotted sitting in a cafe, watching the road to the American ambassador’s residence, before driving away in a gray Volkswagen. In Nigeria, extremists, possibly including a “well-trained” operative just arrived from Chad, were believed to be “planning a massive terrorist attack.” And Persian-language computer hacking sites had posted dangerous “Trojan horse” programs, suggesting how Iranian agents might attack the United States.

headline: Ratify the New Start Treaty
abstract: U.S. Senate approval would set the stage for better relations with Russia and improve European security.
snippet: U.S. Senate approval would set the stage for better relations with Russia and improve European security.
lead_paragraph: NATO’s Lisbon summit meeting last month made historic strides to increase the security of all NATO allies. We reinforced our commitment to collective defense. We renewed NATO’s strategy and vision. We also revitalized our relationship with Russia. There is another step that would contribute directly to increased security in Europe: ratification of the New Start treaty.

headline: Tips for Thanksgiving Shopping
abstract: With many retailers trying to turn Thanksgiving into a new shopping holiday, here are tips for finding the deals.
snippet: With many retailers trying to turn Thanksgiving into a new shopping holiday, here are tips for finding the deals.
lead_paragraph: Forget Black Friday. It’s all about Thanksgiving shopping now. With consumers growing weary, and perhaps more cynical, of Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals, many retailers are now trying to turn Thanksgiving into a new shopping holiday.

headline: TV Channel Draws Viewers, and Threats, in Iran
abstract: The campaign against Farsi1 illustrates the growing fear in Iran over the intrusion of private broadcasters onto the country’s airwaves.
snippet: The campaign against Farsi1 illustrates the growing fear in Iran over the intrusion of private broadcasters onto the country’s airwaves.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  In little more than a year, the Persian-language satellite television channel beamed into Iran by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation and a prominent Afghan family has rapidly become one of the most popular stations in the country.

headline: Europe and America, Aligned for the Future
abstract: Our task at the NATO summit is to revitalize our alliance and ensure our future security and prosperity.
snippet: Our task at the NATO summit is to revitalize our alliance and ensure our future security and prosperity.
lead_paragraph: With this week’s NATO and United States-European Union summit meetings in Lisbon, I am proud to have visited Europe a half-dozen times as president. This reflects an enduring truth of American foreign policy — our relationship with our European allies and partners is the cornerstone of our engagement with the world, and a catalyst for global cooperation.

headline: Baidu Struggled in China, Too
abstract: Baidu’s chief executive, Robin Li, said his company also faced obstacles building its dominant search business in China.
snippet: Baidu’s chief executive, Robin Li, said his company also faced obstacles building its dominant search business in China.
lead_paragraph: Google failed in China because it did not understand the Chinese Internet market, not because the playing field was unfairly tilted against it, said Robin Li, the chief executive of Baidu, the Chinese search engine that dominates in China.

headline: One on One: Vivek Kundra, U.S. Chief Information Officer

snippet: A one-on-one interview with Vivek Kundra, chief information officer of the United States, discussing cyber security, data.gov and social networking.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Kundra is the chief information officer of the United States. His job is to help shape the use of technology in government and build tools to help the public navigate the incredible amount of data and information available.

headline: Pentagon Will Help Homeland Security Department Fight Domestic Cyberattacks
abstract: In the event of a domestic cyberattack, the Homeland Security Department will tap the Pentagon’s expertise.
snippet: In the event of a domestic cyberattack, the Homeland Security Department will tap the Pentagon’s expertise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has adopted new procedures for using the Defense Department’s vast array of cyberwarfare capabilities in case of an attack on vital computer networks inside the United States, delicately navigating historic rules that restrict military action on American soil.

headline: In Europe, Companies Work the Angles on the Carbon Trade

headline: NATO Document Addresses Nuclear Disarmament
abstract: A draft of the new strategic concept includes the goal for the first time, but faces many obstacles from members of the alliance.
snippet: A draft of the new strategic concept includes the goal for the first time, but faces many obstacles from members of the alliance.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Two months before what could be the most important NATO summit meeting in more than a decade, the 28 member states of the alliance have received a draft of its new strategic concept, which for the first time, at the insistence of Germany and other countries, includes calls for nuclear disarmament.

headline: In a Computer Worm, a Possible Biblical Clue
abstract: A reference in computer code to the Book of Esther may or may not be a sign of an Israeli origin to the Stuxnet worm.
snippet: A reference in computer code to the Book of Esther may or may not be a sign of an Israeli origin to the Stuxnet worm.
lead_paragraph: Deep inside the computer worm that some specialists suspect is aimed at slowing Iran’s race for a nuclear weapon lies what could be a fleeting reference to the Book of Esther, the Old Testament tale in which the Jews pre-empt a Persian plot to destroy them.

headline: Three Faces of the New China
abstract: A rising power bullies, cajoles or sidesteps. The pattern can confuse. Or it can reveal China’s real priorities.
snippet: A rising power bullies, cajoles or sidesteps. The pattern can confuse. Or it can reveal China’s real priorities.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In a blur of headlines over the past few days, Americans have been surprised with brief, seemingly contradictory glimpses of how China is wielding its newfound power.

headline: Malware Hits Computerized Industrial Equipment
abstract: The Stuxnet malware, designed to attack industrial control equipment,  marks the first attack on critical industrial infrastructure that sits at the foundation of modern economies.
snippet: The Stuxnet malware, designed to attack industrial control equipment,  marks the first attack on critical industrial infrastructure that sits at the foundation of modern economies.
lead_paragraph: The technology industry is being rattled by a quiet and sophisticated malicious software program that has infiltrated factory computers.

headline: Cyberwar Chief Calls for Secure Computer Network
abstract: The new commander of the military’s cyberwarfare operations is advocating the creation of a separate, secure computer network to protect against attacks mounted over the Internet.
snippet: The new commander of the military’s cyberwarfare operations is advocating the creation of a separate, secure computer network to protect against attacks mounted over the Internet.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The new commander of the military’s cyberwarfare operations is advocating the creation of a separate, secure computer network to protect civilian government agencies and critical industries like the nation’s power grid against attacks mounted over the Internet.

headline: The Terror Translators
abstract: A little-known unit of the New York Police Department relies on civilian analysts to help fight terror threats.
snippet: A little-known unit of the New York Police Department relies on civilian analysts to help fight terror threats.
lead_paragraph: INSPIRE magazine, an English-language journal published by Al Qaeda, included in its summer edition what amounted to a “Friends and Foes” list. There, on Page 4, following the letter from the editor (“We survive through jihad and perish without it”), were pictures of, and quotations from, kindred spirits like Faisal Shahzad, who pleaded guilty in a plot to detonate a car bomb in Times Square, and, perhaps surprisingly, David Letterman, who was praised for recent criticism of former President George W. Bush.

headline: Military Computer Attack Confirmed
abstract: A foreign intelligence agent infected computers in “the most significant breach of U.S. military computers ever.”
snippet: A foreign intelligence agent infected computers in “the most significant breach of U.S. military computers ever.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top Pentagon official has confirmed a previously classified incident that he describes as “the most significant breach of U.S. military computers ever,” a 2008 episode in which a foreign intelligence agent used a flash drive to infect computers, including those used by the Central Command in overseeing combat zones in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
abstract: Books about cyberwarfare, American foreign policy, Theodore Roosevelt and the importance of the humanities.
snippet: Books about cyberwarfare, American foreign policy, Theodore Roosevelt and the importance of the humanities.
lead_paragraph: CYBER WAR  The Next Threat to National Security and What to Do About It.  By Richard A. Clarke and Robert K. Knake.  Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.99.

headline: Eurofile | A Perfect Spring in Summertime Paris
abstract: There’s a delicious consolation for tourists who end up in the City of Light during its annual gastronomic downtime.
snippet: There’s a delicious consolation for tourists who end up in the City of Light during its annual gastronomic downtime.
lead_paragraph: In Alexander Lobrano’s new column, Eurofile, the author of “Hungry for Paris” writes about the best tables (and beds) on the continent.This summer in Paris, there’s a delicious consolation for tourists who end up in the City of Light during its annual gastronomic downtime, and also the legions of Parisians required to remain in the professional saddle while everyone else is whinnying in the surf in Brittany or sipping rosé on a shady terrace in Corsica. (The ultimate place to tipple on the Ile de Beauté this summer, by the way, is the gorgeous Domaine de Murtoli.)

headline: Taking Lessons From 9/11 to a National Level
abstract: New York’s fire commissioner is having an effect on nationwide disaster preparedness.
snippet: New York’s fire commissioner is having an effect on nationwide disaster preparedness.
lead_paragraph: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the Fire Department has worked to bolster its counterterrorism and disaster preparedness repertoires in all sorts of ways – from practical to conceptual.

headline: New Menace in the War Against Online Crime
abstract: The Zeus Trojan, a tool for online criminals, has been staging new targeted attacks against certain banks.
snippet: The Zeus Trojan, a tool for online criminals, has been staging new targeted attacks against certain banks.
lead_paragraph: In the battle against online criminals, a new front has emerged involving Zeus, a data-stealing Trojan horse that infects Windows PCs, according to researchers at Dasient, a Web site security firm founded by Google alumni.

headline: The Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq: Teaching Resources and Essential Questions
abstract: Lesson plans from 2001 to the present about the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, along with selected “essential questions” about the wars, terrorism, U.S. involvement in nation-building, the role of soldiers and the geopolitics of the Middle East.
snippet: Lesson plans from 2001 to the present about the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, along with selected “essential questions” about the wars, terrorism, U.S. involvement in nation-building, the role of soldiers and the geopolitics of the Middle East.

abstract: The Internet affords anonymity to its users, but that very anonymity is also behind the explosion of cybercrime that has swept across the Web.
snippet: The Internet affords anonymity to its users, but that very anonymity is also behind the explosion of cybercrime that has swept across the Web.
lead_paragraph: THE Obama Administration is trying to fix the Internet’s dog problem.

headline: Online Bullies Pull Schools Into the Fray
abstract: Affronted by cyberspace’s escalation of adolescent viciousness, many parents are looking to schools for justice, protection, even revenge.
snippet: Affronted by cyberspace’s escalation of adolescent viciousness, many parents are looking to schools for justice, protection, even revenge.
lead_paragraph: The girl’s parents, wild with outrage and fear, showed the principal the text messages: a dozen shocking, sexually explicit threats, sent to their daughter the previous Saturday night from the cellphone of a 12-year-old boy. Both children were sixth graders at Benjamin Franklin Middle School in Ridgewood, N.J.

headline: Likejacking & Tabnapping

headline: Grid Confronts a Threat from Mother Nature
abstract: A report issued by the Energy Department and the North American Electric Reliability Corporation lists three categories of threats to the North American power grid: coordinated cyber- and physical attacks, pandemic disease and electromagnetic and geomagnetic damage.
snippet: A report issued by the Energy Department and the North American Electric Reliability Corporation lists three categories of threats to the North American power grid: coordinated cyber- and physical attacks, pandemic disease and electromagnetic and ...
lead_paragraph: A report just issued by the Energy Department and the North American Electric Reliability Corporation, known as Nerc, an industry group that polices the power grid, lists three categories of threats to the grid: coordinated cyber- and physical attacks, pandemic disease and electromagnetic damage.

headline: ‘Stop and Frisk’ vs. Privacy, and Good News for Kelly
abstract: In 1 Police Plaza: “Stop and frisk” is discussed from all angles, and a new poll is good news for the police commissioner. (If he cares.)
snippet: In 1 Police Plaza: “Stop and frisk” is discussed from all angles, and a new poll is good news for the police commissioner. (If he cares.)
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, a group of elected officials and others stood at City Hall to fight for what they believe are the privacy rights of New Yorkers who are stopped on the streets by city police officers, but neither arrested nor given a summons.

headline: NATO Urged to Look Beyond Borders
abstract: A proposed new strategy for the alliance emphasizes the dangers of terrorism, piracy and cyber-attacks.
snippet: A proposed new strategy for the alliance emphasizes the dangers of terrorism, piracy and cyber-attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — NATO must be willing to fight and operate far from its borders to defend its members in a new world of terrorism, piracy and cyberattacks, according to a proposed strategy for the alliance released Monday.

headline: The Battle for the Internet
abstract: The defense of human rights must be the priority for governance of the Internet.
snippet: The defense of human rights must be the priority for governance of the Internet.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In 2015, 3.5 billion people — half of mankind — will have access to the Internet. There has never been such a revolution in freedom of communication and freedom of expression. But how will this new medium be used? What obstacles will the enemies of the Internet come up with?

headline: Red Sox Nation Grumbles Like an Entitled Empire
abstract: Red Sox fans have seen this sort of troubled start before, and for longtime devotees, it promises to be a cathartic trip down memory lane.
snippet: Red Sox fans have seen this sort of troubled start before, and for longtime devotees, it promises to be a cathartic trip down memory lane.
lead_paragraph: The Red Sox are off to a troubled start, and barely a sixth of the way into the season, the Web sites and comment boards in Boston are warning of a long and miserable summer. But to any longtime Sox fan — born before, say, 1990 — it just ain’t so. To us, this year promises to be a cathartic trip down memory lane and, maybe, a return to tradition, and sanity.

headline: Advancing Europe’s Security
abstract: America seeks a Europe in which all countries, including Russia, play a full role in facing new threats.
snippet: America seeks a Europe in which all countries, including Russia, play a full role in facing new threats.
lead_paragraph: This week I will sit down with NATO ambassadors to advance the ongoing dialogue among the United States and its closest allies on the future of European security. I do so because the United States is firmly committed to the view that any decisions about Europe’s security must be made in close coordination with our European allies and partners. We will decide nothing about our European allies and partners without them.

headline: Times Square, Bombs and Big Crowds
abstract: How can we prevent terrorist attacks in crowded areas? Do security cameras make a difference?
snippet: How can we prevent terrorist attacks in crowded areas? Do security cameras make a difference?

headline: The Attack Coming From Bytes, Not Bombs

snippet: The United States’ dependence on technology means it could be paralyzed in just 15 minutes, says the former counterterrorism czar Richard A. Clarke.
lead_paragraph: Blackouts hit New York, Los Angeles, Washington and more than 100 other American cities. Subways crash. Trains derail. Airplanes fall from the sky.

headline: Shouldering Waste on the Trek Down Mount Everest
abstract: An explosion in the number of climbers at Mount Everest has prompted the Nepalese authorities to crack down on garbage.
snippet: An explosion in the number of climbers at Mount Everest has prompted the Nepalese authorities to crack down on garbage.
lead_paragraph: In 1963 — just 10 years after the first ascent of Mount Everest by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa guide -– a fellow climber, Dr. Barry Bishop, wrote in National Geographic that parts of the mountain had become “the highest junkyard on the face of the Earth.” Expedition teams were trashing Everest by wantonly disposing of empty oxygen canisters, torn tents and other rubbish at base camp and just a few thousand feet below the summit, Dr. Bishop reported.

headline: Attacks on Military Computers Cited
abstract: Lt. Gen. Keith B. Alexander, nominated to head a new Cyber Command, said the military systems underwent attacks thousands of times a day.
snippet: Lt. Gen. Keith B. Alexander, nominated to head a new Cyber Command, said the military systems underwent attacks thousands of times a day.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Computer networks essential to the Pentagon and military are attacked by individual hackers, criminal groups and nations hundreds of thousands of times every day, according to the officer nominated to lead a cyberwarfare command.

headline: At Internet Conference, Signs of Agreement Appear Between U.S. and Russia
abstract: The two countries, meeting with others at an annual gathering in Germany, worked to find common ground on issues of Web governance, crime and security.
snippet: The two countries, meeting with others at an annual gathering in Germany, worked to find common ground on issues of Web governance, crime and security.
lead_paragraph: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany — For the 140 computer network specialists, law enforcement agents and diplomats from eight countries who met in this German ski resort this week for a Russian-sponsored conference on Internet security, the biggest challenge was finding a common ground to discuss their differences.

headline: Cyberwar Nominee Sees Gaps in Law
abstract: Lt. Gen. Keith B. Alexander, in preparation for a Senate confirmation hearing on Thursday, sketched out the broad battlefield for the Pentagon’s new unit devoted to warfare in cyberspace.
snippet: Lt. Gen. Keith B. Alexander, in preparation for a Senate confirmation hearing on Thursday, sketched out the broad battlefield for the Pentagon’s new unit devoted to warfare in cyberspace.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Army intelligence officer nominated to lead the Pentagon’s new command devoted to warfare in cyberspace has warned Congress that policy directives and legal controls over digital combat are outdated and have failed to keep pace with the military’s technical capabilities.

headline: I Was Hacked in Beijing

snippet: Big men in ill-fitting blazers may no longer tail journalists to interviews. But if you’ve got e-mail, the government may have it, too.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The reality — and my fears — dawned only slowly.

headline: Obama’s Nuclear Modesty

headline: Obama’s Nuclear Strategy Intended as a Message
abstract: The strategy makes just about every nonnuclear state immune from any threat of nuclear retaliation by the United States, but it carves out an exception for Iran and North Korea.
snippet: The strategy makes just about every nonnuclear state immune from any threat of nuclear retaliation by the United States, but it carves out an exception for Iran and North Korea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the heart of President Obama’s new nuclear strategy lies a central gamble: that an aging, oversize, increasingly outmoded nuclear arsenal can be turned to the new purpose of adding leverage to the faltering effort to force Iran and North Korea to rethink the value of their nuclear programs.

headline: Researchers Trace Data Theft to Intruders in China
abstract: Security researchers monitored a spying operation that pilfered documents from the Indian Defense Ministry.
snippet: Security researchers monitored a spying operation that pilfered documents from the Indian Defense Ministry.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Turning the tables on a China-based computer espionage gang, Canadian and United States computer security researchers have monitored a spying operation for the past eight months, observing while the intruders pilfered classified and restricted documents from the highest levels of the Indian Defense Ministry.

headline: ‘Glee,’ ‘Modern Family’ and Craig Ferguson Win Peabody Awards
abstract: The awards, given annually by the University of Georgia’s Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication for excellence in electronic media, also went to “In Treatment” and “Endgame,” as well as programs including “Frontline, “American Masters” and “60 Minutes.”
snippet: The awards, given annually by the University of Georgia’s Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication for excellence in electronic media, also went to “In Treatment” and “Endgame,” as well as programs including “Frontline, “American Masters...
lead_paragraph: What could be more exciting for those singing, dancing, impregnating glee-club kids at William McKinley High School than a victory at sectionals? How about a Peabody Award? On Wednesday “Glee,” the hit Fox series, was named one of the recipients of a George Foster Peabody Award, given annually by the University of Georgia’s Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication for excellence in electronic media, the college said in a news release. The ABC comedy “Modern Family” was also recognized by the Peabody board, as were “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS, the HBO series “In Treatment” and “The No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency” and the PBS movie “Endgame,” about the end of the apartheid era in South Africa.

headline: Google Links Web Attacks to Vietnam Mine Dispute
abstract: Google says it has identified cyber attacks aimed at silencing critics of a Chinese-backed bauxite mining project in Vietnam.
snippet: Google says it has identified cyber attacks aimed at silencing critics of a Chinese-backed bauxite mining project in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Google, fresh off a dispute with China over censorship and intrusion from hackers, says it has identified cyber-attacks aimed at silencing critics of a controversial, Chinese-backed bauxite mining project in Vietnam.

headline: Google Searches for a Foreign Policy
abstract: Nations have interests. So do global information companies. And they’re not always the same.
snippet: Nations have interests. So do global information companies. And they’re not always the same.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Google announced last week that it would shut its censored online search service in China, it was doing more than standing up to a repressive government: it was showing that, with the United States still struggling to develop a foreign policy for the digital age, Internet companies need to articulate their own foreign policies.

headline: From 8 Ball Jackets to Prescription Drugs: What the Bad Guys Want

snippet: 1 Police Plaza: the latest trends in stolen goods; running out of numbers to give to criminals; a letter to the commissioner; and more.

snippet: Should multinationals like Google play a greater role in challenging Beijing’s policies?

headline: Google Details ‘New Approach to China’
abstract: In a post on Google’s official blog on Monday, David Drummond, the company’s senior vice president and chief legal officer, explained “today we stopped censoring our search services—Google Search, Google News, and Google Images—on Google.cn.”
snippet: In a post on Google’s official blog on Monday, David Drummond, the company’s senior vice president and chief legal officer, explained “today we stopped censoring our search services—Google Search, Google News, and Google Images—on Google.cn.”
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Miguel Helft and David Barboza report, in a post on Google’s official blog on Monday, David Drummond, the company’s senior vice president and chief legal officer, announced, “today we stopped censoring our search services—Google Search, Google News, and Google Images—on Google.cn.”

headline: What We’re Reading: Art Fraud, Steve Jobs and Citibank

snippet: Technology tidbits from around the Web selected by Times technology journalists.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s highlights from our “What We’re Reading” feature, in which New York Times technology journalists point out interesting articles they have spotted on the Web:

headline: Military Announces New Social Media Policy
abstract: After months of delay, the Defense Department announced its new social media policy for service members using military computers.
snippet: After months of delay, the Defense Department announced its new social media policy for service members using military computers.
lead_paragraph: Many months behind schedule, the Department of Defense on Friday issued a new policy that, on the surface, seems likely to expand access to popular social networking sites like YouTube, Facebook and Twitter by troops using military computers.

headline: Intel Was Attacked at the Same Time as Google
abstract: Intel said it was the victim of a cyber-attack in January, around the same time that Google was a victim of a broad-based attack that started in China.
snippet: Intel said it was the victim of a cyber-attack in January, around the same time that Google was a victim of a broad-based attack that started in China.
lead_paragraph: 7:20 p.m. | Updated  Adding update from Intel spokesman about the possibility of other similarities between the Google and Intel attacks.

headline: The People We Pay to Look Over Our Shoulders
abstract: At its best “The Watchers” provides an insightful glimpse into how Washington works and how ideas are marketed and sold in the back rooms of power.
snippet: At its best “The Watchers” provides an insightful glimpse into how Washington works and how ideas are marketed and sold in the back rooms of power.
lead_paragraph: At this very moment analysts at the National Security Agency some 30 miles north of the White House are monitoring countless flashpoints of data  cellphone calls to “hot” numbers, an e-mail message on a suspicious server, an oddly worded tweet  as they carom around the globe like pinballs in cyberspace.

headline: Hacking Inquiry Puts China’s Elite in New Light
abstract: Investigators looking into Web attacks on Google traced the intrusions to Jiaotong University and Lanxiang Vocational School, elite Chinese schools with strong American ties.
snippet: Investigators looking into Web attacks on Google traced the intrusions to Jiaotong University and Lanxiang Vocational School, elite Chinese schools with strong American ties.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  With its sterling reputation and its scientific bent, Shanghai Jiaotong University has the feel of an Ivy League institution.

headline: ‘A Digital Doomsday Simulation’

snippet: Your Jokes | Researchers staged a digital doomsday simulation of a cyber-attack that crashed cellphone networks and slowed web traffic to a crawl. In other words, they signed up with Verizon. — Jim Barach, Charleston, W. Va.
